page.title: Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins

revision.text:
The '''Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins''' is an exhibit at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in [[New York City]]. It focuses on [[human evolution]], [[Paleontology|human paleontology]], [[archaeology]] and [[genetics]]. At the time of its opening in 1921, it was the first museum exhibit to discuss the controversial topic of evolution.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/107236a0|last=Osborn|first=Henry Fairfield|authorlink=Henry Fairfield Osborn|title=The Hall of the Age of Man in the American Museum|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=107|pages=236–240|date=1921-04-21|issue=2686}}</ref> Among its many highlights include the [[Cave paintings|Dordogne cave paintings]] and the skeleton of [[Lucy (Australopithecus)|Lucy]].
==Mission== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Hall of Human Origins at the American Museum of Natural History.jpeg| thumb |left|900px|]] --> As stated upon its 2007 reopening, the mission of the hall is to "combine discoveries in the fossil record with the latest genomic science to explore the most profound mysteries of humankind: who we are, where we came from, and what is in store for the future of our species. We will explore human biology and anatomy, trace the path of human evolution, and examine the origins of human creativity."<ref>{{cite web|title=Spitzer Hall of Human Origins|url=http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent-exhibitions/human-origins-and-cultural-halls/anne-and-bernard-spitzer-hall-of-human-origins|publisher=American Museum of Natural History|accessdate=2012-12-26}}</ref>
==Exhibits== The hall starts with the present [[homo sapiens]] and traces its evolution backwards through time, while examining anthropology including [[music]], [[art]] and [[technology]]. As the visitor winds through the hall, significant stops are made by life sized dioramas of ''[[Australopithecus afarensis]]'', ''[[Homo ergaster]]'', [[Neanderthal]], and [[Cro-Magnon]] in an attempt to demonstrate the behaviors and capabilities of human predecessors.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wilford|first=John|title=The Hall of Human Origins Reopens|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/09/arts/design/09orig.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|publisher=The New York TImes|accessdate=2012-12-26}}</ref> By the dioramas are actual archeological finds that showcase the evolution of creativity and brain development.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilford|first=John Noble|authorlink=John Noble Wilford|title=Meet the Relatives. They're Full of Surprises|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2007-02-09|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/09/arts/design/09orig.html?pagewanted=all |accessdate=2009-03-04}}</ref> Also displayed are full-sized casts of important fossils, including the 3.2-million-year-old [[Lucy (Australopithecus)|Lucy]] skeleton and the 1.7-million-year-old [[Turkana Boy]], and ''[[Homo erectus]]'' specimens including a cast of [[Peking Man]].
==In popular culture== [[File:Day117anaturalhistoryzi.JPG|thumb|right|Hall of African Peoples]] In the 1999 film [[Election (1999 film)|Election]], [[Matthew Broderick]]'s character compares his humiliating story to the apelike model of [[Homo ergaster]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:American Museum of Natural History]]

{{Infobox website | name = Architectuul | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = <!-- or: | logocaption = --> | screenshot = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://architectuul.com}} | areas = | offices = | traded to date = | commercial = <!-- "Yes", "No" or leave blank --> | type = | registration = | language = English | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language= | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date = {{Start date and age|df=yes/no|2010}} | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{IncreaseNegative}} {{steady}} {{DecreasePositive}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com ##] (US/Global MM/YYYY) --> | ip = | issn = <!-- ISSN, e.g. 1085-6706 (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | oclc = <!-- OCLC number, useful where an ISSN has not been allocated (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | current_status = | footnotes = }}
'''Architectuul''' is an online architecture [[Library catalog|catalog]] that uses [[crowdsourcing]] to build content. It was founded in 2010 by a team of [[architect]]s, [[graphic designer]]s and [[software engineering|software engineers]].<ref>[http://architectuul.com/about Architectuul]</ref> All of the content and images uploaded to the site use the [[creative commons]] license, making the process similar to [[Wikipedia]]. Architectuul has buildings from various era's with a large range from the 20th Century and rare [[Constructivist architecture]].
Architectuul is utilised as a source by several publications and Universities, including the [[Wall Street Journal]].<ref>[https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2012/12/26/dhaka-journal-five-things-to-do-in-the-concealed-city/ Lahiri, T. 2012. Wall Street Journal - Dhaka Journal: Five Things to Do in the ‘Concealed’ City]</ref><ref>[http://blogs.utexas.edu/utsoa-deepfocus/2011/11/architectuul/ University of Texas]</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://architectuul.com Architectuul]
[[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:Architecture databases]]

{{ infobox bibliographic database | title = ArchiveGrid | image = | caption = | producer = [[OCLC]] | country = United States | history = 2006 to present | languages = | providers = | cost = Free | disciplines = | depth = Index & abstract | formats = archival material descriptions | temporal = | geospatial = | number = | updates = | p_title = | p_dates = | ISSN = | web = http://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/ | titles = }}
'''ArchiveGrid''' is a collection of over five million archival material descriptions, including [[MARC standards|MARC records]] from [[WorldCat]] and finding aids harvested from the web.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/|title=ArchiveGrid|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=OCLC Research|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> It contains archival collections held by thousands of libraries, museums, historical societies, and archives.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/about/|title=ArchiveGrid -- About ArchiveGrid|website=beta.worldcat.org|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref> Contribution to the system is available to any institution.<ref>Making Archival and Special Collections More Accessible. 2015. Dublin, Ohio: OCLC Research.
<nowiki>http://www.oclc.org/content/dam/research/publications/2015/</nowiki>
oclcresearch-making-special-collections-accessible-2015.pdf</ref> Most of the contributions are from United States based institutions, but many other countries are represented, including Canada, Australia, and the United Kingdom.<ref name=":1" /> ArchiveGrid is associated with [[OCLC|OCLC Research]] and helps to advance their goals of making archival collections and materials easier to find.<ref name=":0" /> ArchiveGrid is described as "the ultimate destination for searching through family histories, political papers, and historical records held in archives around the world."<ref>{{cite journal|title=RLG Announces Archivegrid|journal=Advanced Technology Libraries|date=January 2006|volume=35|issue=1|pages=1, 10}}</ref>
==History== [[Research Libraries Group]] (RLG) was founded in 1974 by three universities ([[Columbia University|Columbia]], [[Harvard University|Harvard]], and [[Yale University|Yale]]) and [[The New York Public Library]]. In 1998, RLG launched the RLG Archival Resources database, which offered online access to the holdings of archival collections. RLG began to redesign the database in 2004 in order to make it more useful for researchers.<ref>{{cite web|title=RLG Archival Resources Redesign for ArchiveGrid|url=http://www.oclc.org/research/activities/arrredesign.html|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> As a result of this redesign, RLG launched ArchiveGrid in March 2006.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.econtentmag.com/Articles/News/News-Item/RLG-Launches-ArchiveGrid-15263.htm|title=RLG Launches ArchiveGrid|date=2006-03-07|work=EContent Magazine|access-date=2018-11-21|language=en-US}}</ref> As a result of a grant, ArchiveGrid was freely accessible until May 31, 2006.<ref>{{cite journal|title=RLG Launches ArchiveGrid|journal=Advanced Technology Libraries|date=April 2006|volume=35|issue=4|pages=1, 11}}</ref>
==RLG/OCLC Partnership== In 2006, the RLG and the [[OCLC|Online Computer Learning Center, Inc.]] (OCLC) announced the combining of the two organizations. RLG Programs was formed on July 1, 2006 and became part of the OCLC Programs and Research division.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the OCLC Research Library Partnership|url=http://www.oclc.org/research/partnership/history.html|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> ArchiveGrid was offered as an OCLC subscription-based discovery service from 2006 until it was discontinued in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=ArchiveGri|url=http://www.oclc.org/research/activities/archivegrid.html|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> In 2009, RLG Programs became known as RLG Partnership. The OCLC Research Library Partnership replaced the RLG Partnership in 2011. The five-year period of successfully integrating the RLG Partnership into OCLC was completed 30 June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the OCLC Research Library Partnership|url=http://www.oclc.org/research/partnership/history.html|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> In 2012, ArchiveGrid became a free system, while remaining a part of the OCLC Research project.<ref name=":0" />
== Content and Use == ArchiveGrid provides access to material descriptions, finding aids, and contact information of many archival institutions from many countries. The materials on ArchiveGrid are described as "historical documents, personal papers, family histories, and more," which users can access through a search or the map feature.<ref name=":0" /> On the website, the content is accessible through a clickable map, where users can search in specific areas by clicking on the map or by entering a location. The collections are searchable, initially alphabetically, and can also be seen all together as a list or summary. Users can save and download item descriptions, or search through the recently added section on the homepage. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Falk|first=Patricia K.|date=2017-03-20|title=ArchiveGrid|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07317131.2017.1286855|journal=Technical Services Quarterly|language=en|volume=34|issue=2|pages=218–219|doi=10.1080/07317131.2017.1286855|issn=0731-7131}}</ref> ArchiveGrid considers it's main users to be researchers, specifically faculty, students, and genealogists, and improves the site based on the needs of that group; however, there is an increase in people who want to search through archival materials for hobbies, jobs (such as writers and filmmakers), and other personal interests.<ref name=":0" />
Collections are included directly from archives, and also MARC records from WorldCat which the ArchiveGrid team identifies as archival.<ref name=":0" /> Archives who want to be included can submit a form so that the records can be harvested. Content is re-harvested and re-indexed about every six weeks so finding aids are updated.<ref name=":0" /> Use statistics are available on the ArchiveGrid website, as well as statistics regarding contributors, through [[Google Analytics]]. ArchiveGrid includes collections from:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/|title=ArchiveGrid|website=beta.worldcat.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>
*[[United States]] *[[Canada]] *[[Australia]] *[[Belgium]] *[[Brazil]] *[[Chile]] *[[China]] *[[Colombia]] *[[Denmark]] *[[Egypt]] *[[France]] *[[Germany]] *[[Greece]] *[[Guam]] *[[Hong Kong]] *[[Ireland]] *[[Israel]] *[[Italy]] *[[Jamaica]] *[[Japan]] *[[Mexico]] *[[Netherlands]] *[[New Zealand]] *[[Peru]] *[[Poland]] *[[Russia]] *[[Singapore]] *[[Slovenia]] *[[South Africa]] *[[Spain]] *[[Sweden]] *[[Switzerland]] *[[Taiwan]] *[[Trinidad and Tobago]] *[[Turkey]] *[[United Kingdom]] *[[Vatican City]] *[[Venezuela]]
==External links== *[http://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/ ArchiveGrid - Official website] *[http://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/blog/ ArchiveGrid Blog] *[http://www.oclc.org/research/partnership.html OCLC Research Library Partnership] *[http://www.oclc.org/research/partnership/history.html History of the OCLC Research Library Partnership] *[http://www.oclc.org/research/activities/past.html OCLC Research - Past Activities] *"[https://www.liberquarterly.eu/articles/10.18352/lq.7744/ RLG, Where Museums, Libraries, and Archives Intersect]", by Anne van Camp (2003), ''Liber Quarterly'', vol. 13, no.3/4
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[File:Art Apart Logo.jpg|thumb|right|Art Apart Fair logo]] '''Art Apart Fair''' is Singapore's first<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dev.stcommunities.sg/entertainment/show/st-review/more-art-fairs-are-being-launched |title=More art fairs are being launched |date=11 January 2014 |website=The Straits Times |last=Shetty |first=Deepika |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216095717/http://dev.stcommunities.sg/entertainment/show/st-review/more-art-fairs-are-being-launched |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref> hotel-based boutique art fair. Initially called Worlds Apart Fair in January 2013, the success of the fair encouraged a second edition, later renamed as Art Apart Fair as part of a series of "Apart Fairs".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://sea.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/920838/art-apart-hotel-fair-returns-at-parkroyal-on-pickering|title = Art Apart hotel fair returns at Parkroyal on Pickering|date = 25 June 2013|website = Blouin Art Info|publisher = Blouin Art Info Southeast Asia}}</ref>
Art Apart coincides with Singapore Art Week, an initiative launched by the [[National Arts Council (Singapore)|National Arts Council]], along with the [[Singapore Tourism Board]] and [[Economic Development Board|Singapore Economic Development Board]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nac.gov.sg/art-forms/visual-arts/festivals-events/singapore-art-week-2015 |title=Singapore Art Week 2015 |website=National Arts Council |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213033328/http://www.nac.gov.sg/art-forms/visual-arts/festivals-events/singapore-art-week-2015 |archivedate=13 February 2015 }}</ref>
The fairs take place twice biannually – during January and July – in Singapore. Art Apart made its international debut in London in October 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/about-art-apart-fair/|title = About Art Apart Fair|website = Art Apart Fair London}}</ref> at the Town Hall Hotel. It will be setting its stage in New York in October 2016.
Art Apart Fair serves as a platform to provide support towards emerging artists with the potential to become established. The fair gives artists the opportunity to showcase their works<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/about-art-apart-fair/|title = About Art Apart Fair|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> and gain recognition among art lovers and collectors.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ssphere.com/news/latest-blogs/entry/art-apart-fair-2013-presents-a-canvas-for-the-next-wave-of-asian-artists-to-the-rest-of-the-world.html|title = Art Apart Fair 2013 presents a canvas for the next wave of Asian artists to the rest of the world|date = 15 June 2013|website = SSphere Online|last = Tan|first = Billy}}</ref> In January 2014, some 33 galleries and 1,500 artists' work from countries such as Taiwan, China, Australia, Kazakhstan, Croatia, Japan, Vietnam, Austria, Cambodia, South Korea, Russia, Spain and Germany, were featured.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.todayonline.com/entertainment/arts/art-apart-fair-go-international|title = Art Apart Fair to go international|date = 8 January 2014|website = TODAY Online|last = Aljaru|first = Mysara Bte Mohamad}}</ref>
Some of the galleries that have exhibited with Art Apart are South Korea's [[Seoul Arts Centre]], Shanghai's Nancy Gallery, Madrid's Jorge & Fernando Alcolea Gallery<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.herworldplus.com/lifestyle/stuff-do/art-apart-fair-2013 |title=Art Apart Fair 2013 |website=Her World Plus |publisher=Singapore Press Holdings |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025955/http://www.herworldplus.com/lifestyle/stuff-do/art-apart-fair-2013 |archivedate=24 September 2015 }}</ref> and Russia's Gallery 11.12.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.expatliving.sg/Things_to_do/whats_on_calendar/art-and-culture/Art-Fair-Art-Apart-Fair-2015-76210.ece|title = Art Apart Fair 2015|website = Expat Living}}</ref>
In comparison to other art fairs, Art Apart focuses on selecting galleries with emerging artists with a possibility of becoming established in their national or international market.
Due to the high costs of exhibiting at art fairs and the presence of many artists struggling to succeed financially,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/pressrelfinallogo.pdf|title = Art Apart Fair – Singapore returns for its fourth edition|date = 8 May 2014|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> there is an "Adopt An Artist" initiative, where a Patron of the Arts<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/patrons/|title = Patron of the Arts|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> and sponsors help to fund these artists. Galleries that are invited to showcase new works at Art Apart also help support the emerging artists by paying for the exhibiting fee. Works have to be new and not shown at other art fairs before.
Besides providing support for emerging artists, part of the revenue generated from the sales of art works and tickets goes towards helping the young and elderly in Singapore. One of the beneficiaries includes [[Halogen Foundation (Singapore)|Halogen Foundation]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://main.artapartfair.com/assets/uploads/files/aaf_jan_catalogue.pdf |title=Art Apart Fair 3rd Edition Catalogue |website=Art Apart Fair |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216102258/http://main.artapartfair.com/assets/uploads/files/aaf_jan_catalogue.pdf |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref> an educational charity that helps to develop young leaders and entrepreneurs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.halogen.sg/home/about-us/|title = About Us|publisher = Halogen Foundation}}</ref> Another beneficiary is the Lions Befrienders Service Association,<ref name=":0" /> Singapore's largest direct service voluntary welfare organisation, that assists the elderly and helps them engage with the community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lionsbefrienders.org.sg/aboutlbsa_ourhistory.html |title=Our History |website=Lions Befrienders |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216103049/http://www.lionsbefrienders.org.sg/aboutlbsa_ourhistory.html |archivedate=16 February 2015 }}</ref>
== History == The idea of holding an art fair in a hotel first originated in 1994 as the [[The Armory Show (art fair)|Gramercy International Art Fair]] in the rooms of [[Gramercy Park Hotel]] in New York City. The fair was highly successful, and it is now renamed "[[The Armory Show (art fair)|The Armory Show]]".
The concept of a hotel-based art fair breaks the conventional presentation of art in a whitewashed gallery space.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = http://sg.asia-city.com/events/news/art-apart-fair-2014-brings-art-hotel-third-time-jan-17-19|title = Art Apart Fair is set to take place at PARKROYAL hotel this month|date = 14 January 2014|website = The Insider's Guide to Singapore}}</ref> Visitors are provided with a good idea of how these works would look like in a home setting, as they are being displayed in a more informal setting, such as on beds, table tops, chairs and even bathrooms.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.artitute.com/2013/01/24/a-new-art-fair-worlds-apart-singapore/|title = A new art fair – Worlds Apart Singapore|date = 24 January 2013|website = Artitute|last = Anthony|first = Nicola}}</ref>
Inspired by this layout, Art Apart founder and director Rosalind Lim decided to bring the idea over to Singapore. With over 38 years of experience in diverse fields, such as Public Relations, Branding, Marketing and Event Management, she built the foundation for the first successful hotel art fair – the Worlds Apart Fair in January 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/about-the-organizer/|title = About the Organizer|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref> at [[Conrad Centennial Singapore]]. The fair was later renamed Art Apart Fair<ref name=":1"/> and moved to [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]], where the entire 14th floor – rooms, lobbies and corridors – is converted into art galleries.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/welcome/|title = Welcome|website = Art Apart Fair}}</ref>
== Singapore Editions ==
=== Worlds Apart Fair (First Edition) === The inaugural edition of Worlds Apart Fair was held from 25 to 27 January 2013 in 40 rooms at [[Conrad Centennial Singapore]], and saw more than 3,000 visitors and buyers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mynewsdesk.com/sg/luxy-international/pressreleases/art-apart-fair-2014-its-worlds-apart-942925|title = Art Apart Fair 2014 'Its Worlds Apart'|date = 27 December 2013|website = My News Desk}}</ref> The fair showcased some 3,400 art works, ranging from paintings and photography to video art, sculptures and installations.<ref name=":4"/>
Worlds Apart Fair featured emerging contemporary artists from Asia, Africa, Lebanon, Europe, the Americas and Australia, with a greater focus on rising artists from Singapore.<ref name=":4"/> Some of the galleries that exhibited in clude [[Vertical Submarine]] (Singapore), Villa Del Arte Galleries (Spain) and Art Bridge Contemporary (Korea).
Two Chinese talents, Singaporean actor [[Qi Yuwu]] and renowned Chinese artist [[Feng Zhengjie]] collaborated for the first time specially for this fair and presented their work 'Showcase on Print'.
=== Art Apart Fair (Second Edition) === Worlds Apart was renamed as Art Apart as part of a series of "Apart Fairs".
The second edition of Art Apart was held from 5 to 7 July 2013 at [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]], and featured over 120 Asian artists and galleries. The art works were focused on Korea and revolved around themes such as "Korean Wave", "Asian Spirit" and "Butterfly Effect".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://comesingapore.com/events/view/21924/art-apart-fair-2013|title = Art Apart Fair 2013|website = Come Singapore}}</ref>
In addition to the display of artworks, the fair included talks by prominent artists and industry experts from around Asia.<ref name=":2"/>
About 3,000 visitors attended Art Apart Fair 2nd Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Third Edition) === The third edition of Art Apart took place from 17 to 19 January 2014, showcased more than 1,500 art pieces<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2014/01/17/beyond-art-stage-singapore/|title = Beyond Art Stage Singapore|date = 17 January 2014|website = Scene Asia|last = Ang|first = Kristiano}}</ref> from 12 countries, including Germany, South Korea, Russia and the Philippines.<ref name=":3"/>
Besides housing exhibitions such as "The Destruction of the Readymade Everyday", the main theme for Art Apart 3rd Edition was "The Artists' Garden" – a selection of 100 art pieces from the 33 participating galleries.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1000666/singapore-connection-brings-new-hotel-art-fair-to-london|title = Singapore 'connection' brings new hotel art fair to London|date = 12 January 2014|website = Blouin Art Info|publisher =Blouin Art Info International |last = Kolesnikov-Jessop|first = Sonia}}</ref>
Over 4,000 people visited the art fair, an increase from the 2nd Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Fourth Edition) === The fourth edition of Art Apart was held from 18 to 20 July 2014, where more than 2,000 art pieces were exhibited, with a focus on works by Russian artists. The aim of the event was to introduce Eastern European Art, such as works from Moscow, Kazakhstan, Croatia and Slovenia.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://artapartfair.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Fireflyz.pdf|title = Worlds Apart|last = Chew|first = Esther|work = Fireflyz|access-date = }}</ref>
Apart from the display of art pieces, there were live paintings of portraits, talks by Russian art experts and Russian Art Performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-singapore-4th-edition/ |title=Art Apart Fair Singapore – 4th Edition |website=Singapore Art Gallery Guide |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112012/http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-singapore-4th-edition/ |archivedate=2 April 2015 }}</ref>
Similar to the previous edition, over 4,000 visitors visited Art Apart 4th Edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Fifth Edition) === The fifth edition of Art Apart was held from 23 to 25 January 2015 at [[Parkroyal|Parkroyal on Pickering]]. Unlike past editions where the curations were focused on specific countries, such as Singapore, Korea and Russia, this edition showcased [[contemporary art]], highlighted conceptual art works and urban art works by street artists from all around the world. Some of the featured artists include emerging Russian artists [[Rinat Voligamsi]] and [[Maxim Bashev]], German artist Kaja el Attar and French artist Bruno Tanquerel.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sg.asia-city.com/events/singapore-art/art-apart-5th-edition?page=2|title = Art Apart 5th Edition|website = The Insider's Guide to Singapore}}</ref>
Eight galleries from the previous editions of Art Apart made a return, such as Utterly Art, Gaze Gallery and [[Seoul Arts Centre]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sagg.info/event/art-apart-fair-2015/|title = Art Apart Fair 2015|website = Singapore Art Gallery Guide}}</ref>
Over 4,000 visitors attended the fifth edition of the art fair.
=== Art Apart Fair (Sixth Edition) ===
The sixth edition of Art Apart was held from 17 to 19 July 2015. Art Apart Fair featured artworks from the Philippines. The finest Filipino galleries including Big and Small, Gallery Qube, Art Quartel and more showcased the best of contemporary Filipino artworks. Leading the pack of Filipino artists was glass artist Ramon Orlina, who showcased pieces from his stellar three decades in the industry. The art works of Ronald Ventura, the auctions record-holder for Southeast Asian paintings, as well as Geraldine Javier, Marina Cruz, Randy Salon and more were present at the sixth edition.
=== Art Apart Fair (Seventh Edition) === The seventh edition of Art Apart will be held from 22 to 24 January 2016. Art Apart Fair will see the participation of more than 40 Singaporean artists alongside others hailing from Malaysia, Thailand, Korea, Iceland, America, Philippines, Russia and France. The Fair is possibly the largest ensemble of fresh, emerging Singaporean artists in an art fair and signals a shift in focus from previous editions that focused on a matrix of foreign artists and art genre. The Presidential Suite will be themed "Mosaic" and feature never-before-seen works of Benny Ong, Daniela Beltrani's curated selection of 12 Singapore-based artworks and Rosalind Lim's selection of designers-turned-artists, Hayden Ng and luxury shoe designer Mashizan Masjum. Author Bryan Koh will also be presenting his books at the Fair.
== Overseas Editions == Unlike the Singapore Editions, where the fairs are conducted biannually, the fairs held overseas – more specifically London and New York – will take place biennially.<ref name=":6"/>
=== Art Apart London (First Edition) === Art Apart made its international debut from 17 to 19 October 2014 at the Town Hall Hotel, in [[Bethnal Green]], East London. The show is believed to be the first hotel art fair that took place in London in a larger scale.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.londonlive.co.uk/news/2014-10-17/the-art-apart-fair|title = Book a room, browse the art – The Art Apart Fair|date = 17 October 2014|website = London Live}}</ref> The fair showcased over 2,000 contemporary works from more than 100 rising and mid-career artists, including artists such as Oscar Lett, Russell Marshall and Nikolai Ishchuk,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://artapartfair.com/london/artists/|title = Art Apart Fair 2014, Artists }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://madeinshoreditch.co.uk/events/the-art-apart-fair/|title = The Art Apart Fair|website = Made in Shoreditch}}</ref> occupying the entire second floor of the hotel. Besides featuring artists, art pieces by silversmiths, jewellers and makers, such as Hans Stofer and David Clarke were exhibited as well. Over 3,000 visitors were expected to be present for the Art Apart London 1st Edition.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.russianartandculture.com/event-art-apart-art-fair-2014-the-town-hall-hotel-london-17-19-october/|title = Art Apart Fair 2014, The Town Hall Hotel, London, 17 – 19 October 2014|date = 11 July 2014|website = Russian Art and Culture}}</ref>
=== Art Apart New York (First Edition) === Art Apart is expected to debut in New York in March 2016.
=== Art Apart London (Second Edition) === The second edition of Art Apart in London is expected to be held in October 2016.

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox publisher | image = [[File:Albums Pléiade.JPG|200px]] | caption = Some ''[[Album de la Pléiade|albums de la Pléiade]]'' | parent = [[Éditions Gallimard]] | status = | founded = 1931 | founder = Jacques Schiffrin | successor = | country = [[France]] | headquarters = [[Paris]] | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = [[Book]]s | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|http://www.la-pleiade.fr}} }}
[[File:Reliure bibliothèque de la Pléiade.jpg|thumb|Detailed view of the quality binding of a volume in the ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'']] [[File:Neuf livres dans la collection Bibliothèque de La Pléiade.jpg|thumb|Nine books in the Pléiade collection]]
The '''''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade''''' ({{IPA-fr|bi.bli.jɔ.tɛk də la ple.jad|}}, "[[Pleiades]] Library") is a [[France|French]] [[Collection (publishing)|editorial collection]] which was created in 1931 by [[Jacques Schiffrin]], an independent young editor. Schiffrin wanted to provide the public with reference editions of the complete works of classic authors in a pocket format. [[André Gide]] took an interest in Schiffrin's project and brought it into [[Éditions Gallimard|Gallimard]], under which it is still published.
The Pléiade has a strong emphasis on works that were originally written in [[French language|French]], though the collection also includes classics of world literature, such as bilingual editions of the works of [[William Shakespeare]], or French editions of [[Jane Austen]]'s work. To date, more than eight hundred books have been published in the series, with eleven books generally published every year. The "entry into the Pléiade" is considered a major sign of recognition for an author in France, and it is extremely rare that a living author is published in the ''Pléiade''.
In 1992, Gallimard and [[Giulio Einaudi Editore|Einaudi]] began a similar series of literature in Italian, the ''[[Biblioteca della Pléiade]]''.<ref>WorldCat, "[http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=%22biblioteca+della+pleiade%22&fq=dt%3Abks&dblist=638&qt=sort&se=yr&sd=asc&qt=sort_yr_asc Biblioteca della Pléiade]".</ref> The ''[[Library of America]]'' series, launched in 1979, is a similar project in the United States inspired by the ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade''.
== History ==
The ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'' was founded by Jacques Schiffrin in 1931. The first volume published was the first tome of the complete works of [[Charles Baudelaire]], on 10 September 1931. André Gide and [[Jean Schlumberger]], creators of the ''Nouvelle Revue française'' (NRF), took interest in this, and integrated the collection into [[Éditions Gallimard|Gallimard]] on 31 July 1936. In 1939, André Gide became the first author to be published while still living, with the partial publication of his diary. In 1940, Jacques Schiffrin was fired by [[Gaston Gallimard]] because of the anti-Jewish laws. Jean Paulhan took the direction of the collection. After moving to New York to escape Nazism, Schiffrin became a founder of [[Pantheon Books]].
Directors of the collection: * 1931–1940 : Jacques Schiffrin * 1960–1966 : Jean Ducourneau * 1966–1987 : Pierre Buge * 1988–1996 : Jacques Cotin * After 1997 : Hugues Pradier
== Books == [[File:Baudelaire, La Pléiade, reliure.jpg|thumb|left|100px|Spine with gold lettering]] [[File:Jacquette des Œuvres complètes de Baudelaire, La Pléiade.jpg|thumb|Title page of a work of [[Charles Baudelaire]] in the ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'']] [[File:Top10 Pleiade.JPG|thumb|]]
=== Binding ===
All the books offer a similar high quality appearance—leather bound, with gold lettering on the spine and [[bible paper]], and they have a practical small format which makes them look like small Bibles. The use of bible paper allows the books to contain a high number of pages; it is common for a Pléiade book to contain 1500. The longest volume in the Pléiade is ''[[One Thousand and One Nights|Les mille et une nuits]]'' I, II et III, at 3504 pages.
The leather covers of the books are also colour-coded according to period: 20th century literature comes in tobacco leather, 19th century in emerald green, 18th century in blue, 17th century in Venetian red, 16th in Corinthian brown, the Middle Ages purple, Antiquity green, spiritual texts grey, and anthologies red. The books are sold in a transparent [[Celluloid|rhodoïd]] [[dust jacket]], and inserted in a white printed cardboard slipcase, although multiple volumes are often sold in a single slipcase.
=== Edition === The books are critical editions, with annotations, comments, manuscript and editorial variants and accompanying documents. The preparation of these critical editions can take many years for a team of specialists, which accounts partly for the books' generally steep cost. For works written in languages other than French, new French translations are usually created.<ref>One example where a new translation was not made is ''Ulysses'', by [[James Joyce]]. The Morel translation from 1929 was used.</ref>
In the 1960s and 1970s, an ''Encyclopédie de la Pléiade'' in the same format was also created, under the direction of [[Raymond Queneau]].
== Authors published == At the beginning of 2017, the collection includes nearly 800 books and more than 250 authors (collective works excluded): * ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'' : 787 volumes; * ''Albums de la Pléiade'' : 56 volumes; * ''[[Encyclopédie de la Pléiade]]'' : 54 volumes
The authors who were alive when published in the ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'' are:<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.frenchculture.org/spip.php?article4147 |title=Archived copy |access-date=14 April 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728011531/http://www.frenchculture.org/spip.php?article4147 |archive-date=28 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[René Char]] (1983) * [[Paul Claudel]] (1948) * [[André Gide]] (1939, 1st) * [[Julien Gracq]] (1989) * [[Julien Green]] (1998) * [[Eugène Ionesco]] (1991) * [[Philippe Jaccottet]] (2014, 15th)<ref>[http://www.rts.ch/info/culture/5614654-le-poete-vaudois-philippe-jaccottet-entre-de-son-vivant-dans-la-pleiade.html "Le poète vaudois Philippe Jaccottet entre de son vivant dans La Pléiade"], [[Radio télévision suisse|www.rts.ch]] (page visited on 14 February 2014).</ref><ref>[http://www.la-pleiade.fr/Auteur/Philippe-Jaccottet "Philippe Jaccottet"], www.la-pleiade.fr (page visited on 14 February 2014).</ref> * [[Milan Kundera]] (2011, 14th)<ref>[http://www.ceskapozice.cz/en/blog/michael-stein/kundera-joins-la-pleiade "Kundera joins La Pléiade"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313091730/http://www.ceskapozice.cz/en/blog/michael-stein/kundera-joins-la-pleiade |date=13 March 2011 }}, www.ceskapozice.cz (page visited on 14 February 2014).</ref> * [[Jean d'Ormesson]] (2015, 16th) * [[Claude Lévi-Strauss]] (2008, 13th) * [[André Malraux]] (1947) * [[Roger Martin du Gard]] (1955) * [[Henry de Montherlant]] (1972) * [[Nathalie Sarraute]] (1996) * [[Saint-John Perse]] (1972) * [[Marguerite Yourcenar]] (1982) * [[Mario Vargas Llosa]] (2016) * [[Philip Roth]] (2017)}}
== Albums == {{Main article|Album de la Pléiade}}
The ''Bibliothèque de la Pléiade'' also publishes an [[Album de la Pléiade]] every Summer, which is an illustrated book in the same format as the rest of the series, usually dedicated to one of the writers but sometimes also dedicated to writers from a specific time period (1989 album) or to an important topic (1970 and 2009 albums) from the collection. The Albums are offered for free with the purchase of three books in the series. They are often collected.
== See also == * [[Library of America]]
== Notes and references == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Bibliothèque de la Pléiade}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title | image = Boule et Bill.png | caption = Boule and Bill with the logo of the series | imagesize = 204 | title = Boule et Bill | format = [[Bande dessinée]] | publisher = [[Dupuis]], [[Dargaud]] (in French)
[[Cinebook Ltd]] (in English) | date = 1959–present | main_char_team = Boule, Bill | writers = [[Jean Roba]] (until 2003) | artists = Jean Roba | colorists = | creators = Jean Roba, [[Maurice Rosy]] }}'''''Boule et Bill''''' (known in English as '''''Billy & Buddy''''') is a popular [[comics|comic]], created in 1959 by the [[Franco-Belgian comics|Belgian]] [[comic book creator|writer-artist]] [[Jean Roba]] in collaboration with [[Maurice Rosy]].{{Cite web|last=Lambiek Comiclopedia|title=Jean Roba|url=http://www.lambiek.net/artists/r/roba.htm}} In 2003, the artistic responsibility of the series was passed on to Roba's former assistant Laurent Verron. The stories center on a typical family: a man and his wife, their young son Boule and Bill the [[English Cocker Spaniel|cocker spaniel]]. ==History== ''Boule et Bill'' first appeared in the [[Belgian comics]] magazine ''[[Spirou (magazine)|Spirou]]'' on December 24, 1959.{{Cite web|last=BDoubliées|title=Spirou année 1959|url=http://bdoubliees.com/journalspirou/annees/1959.htm|language=French}} The ambition was to make a sort of European [[Peanuts]]. The debut was made in a so-called ''[[Spirou (magazine)#Rejuvenation in the 1960s and 1970s|mini-récit]]'' (mini-story), a story in 32 very small pages, printed on the inner spread of the magazine. Roba had until then mainly made illustrations for the magazine and had helped some other authors (including [[André Franquin]]), and now started with his own series. A few months later, a four-page comic with the same heroes appeared, and shortly thereafter Roba created a weekly one page comic. For the next twenty-five years, ''Boule et Bill'' was one of the most popular series of the magazine, and appeared mostly on the back cover. Some of the strips were even published in the rival ''[[Le Journal de Mickey]]'', which was based mainly around [[Walt Disney]] characters like [[Mickey Mouse]] and [[Donald Duck]]. From 1961 to 1965, the strip appeared in British comic [[Valiant (comics)|Valiant]], renamed ''It's A Dog's Life''. Boule's name was changed to Pete and Bill's was changed to Larry. Apart from those changes this strip was mostly the same. 21 Albums were edited by [[Dupuis]] until 1985, containing one long story and some 800 gags. Thereafter, Roba changed from editor, moving to [[Dargaud]]. In 2006, Jean Roba died, but he had announced that he wanted the series to be continued, and had appointed Verron as his successor. ==Story== ''Boule et Bill'' relates the homely adventures of seven-year-old boy Boule and his dog Bill, a [[Cocker Spaniel]], as well as that of Boule's mother and father and Caroline the [[turtle]]. Bill, while slightly [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphized]], basically acts as a normal dog, and the whole series places comical adventures in the [[slice of life|realistic setting of a normal family in a normal town, with normal lives]]. Most of the gags happen in or around the house, but also include an almost yearly holiday setting with the family travelling away from home, usually at the beach. ===Characters=== * '''Boule''' is a young boy, always dressed in a blue overalls and a yellow T-shirt. He is an ordinary boy who goes to school and has friends with whom he plays a lot. * '''Bill''' is a [[Cocker Spaniel]]. He can't speak but resorts to many tricks to make himself understood. He can communicate with other animals, such as his best friend, Caroline. He is very resourceful and cunning to find food, likes sleeping on sofas but dislikes bathing. Some of the most recurring gags revolve around Boule and his dad tricking Bill into a bathtub for a reluctant wash. His long ears provide him with many abilities. * '''Boule's mother''' stays at home and complies with domestic tasks. Her concerns are to keep the house clean and to prevent disasters from Boule and Bill's ideas. * '''Boule's father''' tries to educate his son properly by taking advantage of his questions and blunders. However, he fails most of the time, even if he is quite proud of his personal knowledge. He works for an advertising company, likes gardening and sleeping on the sofa, which is also appreciated by Bill, which provides some recurring gags. * '''Caroline''' is a green turtle who belongs to Boule's family. She lives in the garden. When Bill first met her, he feared she could eat his bones, but was then reassured, for she eats only lettuce. Caroline is [[insomnia]]c. * '''Madame Stick''' is the neighbour of Boule's family. The widow of a colonel, she is very strict and severe. She is the owner of Corporal, a cat who is Bill's arch enemy. * '''Gérard''' is a young snobbish boy and owns a dog similar to him. He tries to dwarf Boule and Bill but ends up being overcome by their inventiveness. * '''Monsieur Coupon-Dubois''' is the boss of Boule's father. A very respectable man, Boule's father sometimes invites him to his home or is being trusted with precious objects, and finds it difficult to prevent Bill's blunders. * '''Pouf''' is Boule's best friend, but is also a rival for Bill, who often teases him. He wears long hair which covers most of his head and a cap. * '''Hildegarde''' is Pouf's cousin who lives in the country. She appeared a few times in the series. * '''Boule's teacher''' ==Original albums== Boule et Bill were first published by [[Dupuis]], then from 1988 by [[Dargaud]]. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} # ''Tel Boule, tel Bill'' # ''Boule et Bill déboulent'' # ''Les Copains d'abord'' # ''Système Bill'' # ''Bulle et Bill'' # ''Tu te rappelles, Bill ?'' # ''Bill ou Face'' # ''Souvenirs de famille'' # ''Le fauve est lâché'' # ''Bill, chien modèle'' # ''Bill de match # ''Sieste sur ordonnance'' # ''Papa, Maman, Boule et... moi'' # ''Une vie de chien'' # ''Attention chien marrant !'' # ''Jeux de Bill'' {{Col-break}} # ''Ce coquin cocker'' # ''Carnet de Bill'' # ''Ras le Bill'' # ''Bill, nom d'un chien !'' # ''Bill est maboul'' # ''Globe-trotters'' # ''Strip-Cocker'' # ''Billets de Bill'' # Les V'là !, 1999 # Faut rigoler !, 1999 # Bwouf allo Bill ?, 1999 # Les Quatre Saisons, 2001 # Quel cirque !, 2003 # La Bande à Bill, 2005 # Graine de cocker, 2007 # Mon meilleur ami, 2009 {{col-end}} ==Other publications== * In 1999, the Boule et Bill series was entirely reedited by Dupuis, in albums of 48 strips, whereas the former albums were composed of either 64, 56 or 48 pages. This series consists of 24 albums published by Dupuis plus three albums originally published by Dargaud and reedited. The nine first albums of the original collection were replaced by 14 albums with different names. The other albums kept their original names, apart from the former 22nd album which was renamed ''Les v'la!''. This new series went on after Roba's death with three new albums drawn by Verron: ''Quel Cirque!'' (2003), ''La bande à Bill'' (2005), ''Graine de cocker'' (2007). * In 1979 ''Une extraordinaire aventure de Boule et Bill: Bill a disparu !'' was published in ''Spirou''; written by [[André-Paul Duchateau]], Bill goes missing and the various characters from ''Spirou'' magazine search for him. * In 1987 ''L'album de famille de Boule et Bill'' was published by Dargaud. * In 1997 ''Boule et Bill en famille'' was published. * In 1999 ''Boule et Bill font la fête'' was published in commemoration of Boule et Bill's 40th anniversary. * Four ''Best of Boule et Bill'' albums composed of previously published strips were published in 2003 and 2004: ''Plumes poils et compagnie'', ''En vadrouille'', ''Jeux d'hiver'', and ''Home sweet home''. * A series of books for children was published in pocket format, illustrated by Roba and written by [[Fanny Joly]], published by Mango as part of the ''Bibliomango'' line. * An album, ''A l'école ... vite !'', was published in 1999 by [[Atlas (editions)|Atlas]]. * Various special advertising albums were published. ==English translations== [[Cinebook]] has published three books in English, with ''Boule and Bill'' renamed ''Billy and Buddy'', respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinebook.co.uk/index.php?cPath=155|title=Billy & Buddy|website=www.cinebook.co.uk|accessdate=10 November 2017}} # Remember this, Buddy? – Jun 2009 – {{ISBN|978-1-905460-91-5}} # Bored Silly with Billy – Sep 2010 – {{ISBN|978-1-84918-049-8}} # Friends First – Jun 2012 – {{ISBN|978-1-84918-124-2}} ==Impact== ''Boule et Bill'' is among the best-selling French-language comics, with 300,000 copies for the new album by Verron in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.acbd.fr/bilan-2009.html |title=Bilan 2009 |date=December 2009 |publisher=ACBD |accessdate=6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114103127/http://www.acbd.fr/bilan-2009.html |archivedate=January 14, 2010 }} ===Film adaptations=== In 2013 a Belgian-French-Luxembourgian film was released, "Boule et Bill", based on the comics. It stars Franck Dubosc as the father, Marina Foïs as the mother, and Charles Crombez as Bill. It received bad reviews,{{cite web|url=http://www.allocine.fr/film/fichefilm_gen_cfilm=134691.html|title=Boule & Bill|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}} but was commercially successful enough to warrant a sequel "Boule et Bill 2", released in 2017. ===Television adaptations=== Four animated television series based on ''Boule and Bill'' were produced: *[[Boule et Bill (1960 TV series)]] broadcast on [[Radiodiffusion-Télévision Française|RTF]] *[[Boule et Bill (2000 TV series)]] broadcast on [[TF1]] *[[Boule et Bill (2004 TV series)]] broadcast on [[Unis (TV channel)]] with 104 episodes{{cite web |url=http://unis.ca/boule-et-bill/?e=mj5h2a7xooeph |title=Plein les yeux - Boule et Bill - Émissions - Unis TV |website=[[Unis.ca]] |quote=ÉPISODE 104 ANNÉE DE PRODUCTION : 2004}} *[[Boule et Bill (2006 TV series)]] broadcast on [[TOU.TV]] with 104 episodes{{cite web |url=http://ici.tou.tv/boule-et-bill/S2015E104 |title=Boule et Bill - ICI Tou.tv |website=[[tou.tv]] |quote=L'oeuf de Caroline
Titre : Saison 2015 Épisode 104
Année de production : 2005}} appears to be a re-dubbing of the 2004 series with the stories in a different order ===Video game adaptations=== A [[Nintendo DS]] video game based on the comic was launched in 2008 by [[Atari]] and [[Anuman Interactive]].{{cite web |url=http://www.afjv.com/press0807/080730_anuman_atari_catalogue.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001937/http://www.afjv.com/press0807/080730_anuman_atari_catalogue.htm |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} ===Tributes=== In the [[Belgian Comic Strip Center]] in [[Brussels]] the permanent exhibition brings homage to the pioneers of [[Belgian comics]], among them Jean Roba and his series ''Boule et Bill''.http://www.tento.be/sites/default/files/tijdschrift/pdf/OKV1992/Belgisch%20Centrum%20van%20het%20Beeldverhaal%20Brussel.pdf Boule et Bill is among the many Belgian comics characters to jokingly have a Brussels street named after them. The Rue au Beurre/ Boterstraat has a [[commemorative plaque]] with the name ''Rue Boule et Bill / Bollie en Billie straat'' placed under the actual street sign.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebru.be/Other/Strips/bruxelles-1000-noms-de-rue-bd.html|title=eBru - Bruxelles Capitale de la Bande Dessinėe (BD) - Noms de rue|website=www.ebru.be|accessdate=10 November 2017}} In 1992 a wall painting representing ''Boule and Bill'' was painted in the Rue du Chevreuil in [[Brussels]].{{cite web|url=https://marocomicsblog.wordpress.com/boule-et-bill/#boulebill|title=Boule et bill|date=18 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}} It was designed by G. Oregopoulos and D. Vandegeerde. In 2000 http://archives.lesoir.be/boule-et-bill-jouent-a-saute-mouton-a-jette_t-20001002-Z0JR8C.html a statue of Boule and Bill was erected in [[Jette]], [[Belgium]],{{cite web|url=http://bdmurales.skynetblogs.be/tag/1/boule+et+bill|title=boule et bill : BD & Fresques murales|website=bdmurales.skynetblogs.be|accessdate=10 November 2017}} next to where Roba lived. It was sculpted by Tom Frantzen.{{cite web|url=http://www.objectible.net/objectible/Interviews/InterviewRoba/|title=Interview de Roba|website=www.objectible.net|accessdate=10 November 2017}} In 2014 the statue was subject of vandalism.{{cite web|url=http://www.lacapitale.be/1115906/article/2014-10-03/scandale-a-jette-l-oreille-de-bill-le-chien-sciee|title=Scandale à Jette: l'oreille de Bill le chien sciée!|first=|last=sudinfo.be|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}} In 2002 [[La Poste (France)|La Poste]], France's [[post office]] system, issued two [[postage stamp]]s illustrating Boule and Bill. Three out of eight were [[semi-postal]] stamps benefiting the [[French Red Cross]].http://dominique.hochereau.free.fr/bd/boule%20et%20bill.htm ==Sources== {{Refbegin}} * [http://bdoubliees.com/journalspirou/series1/bouleetbill.htm ''Boule et Bill'' publications in ''Spirou''] BDoubliées {{fr icon}} * [http://www.bedetheque.com/serie-218-BD-Boule-et-Bill--1-.html ''Boule et Bill'' albums] Bedetheque {{fr icon}} {{Refend}} ;Footnotes {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081228030549/http://membres.lycos.fr/boule1bill/ Toute la Para-BD Boule et Bill] Non official site {{fr icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081120102300/http://www.dupuis.com/servlet/jpecat?pgm=VIEW_SERIE&lang=UK&SERIE_ID=16 On Dupuis website] {{en icon}} * [http://verron-laurent.com/accueils/biographie Le site internet du dessinateur Laurent VERRON] {{DEFAULTSORT:Boule Et Bill}} [[Category:Franco-Belgian comics]] [[Category:Belgian comic strips]] [[Category:Dupuis titles]] [[Category:Dargaud titles]] [[Category:Series of books]] [[Category:Belgian comics characters]] [[Category:1959 comics debuts]] [[Category:Comics about dogs]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1959]] [[Category:Child characters in comics]] [[Category:Humor comics]] [[Category:Gag-a-day comics]] [[Category:Fictional dogs]] [[Category:Comic strip duos]] [[Category:Fictional Belgian people]] [[Category:Comics adapted into animated series]] [[Category:Comics adapted into television series]] [[Category:Belgian comics adapted into films]] [[Category:Comics adapted into video games]]

<!-- Please do not remove or change this AfD message until the discussion has been closed. --> {{Article for deletion/dated|page=COCORIOKO Newspaper|timestamp=20181125200442|year=2018|month=November|day=25|substed=yes}} <!-- Once discussion is closed, please place on talk page: {{Old AfD multi|page=COCORIOKO Newspaper|date=25 November 2018|result='''keep'''}} --> <!-- End of AfD message, feel free to edit beyond this point --> {{Infobox newspaper | image = COCORIOKO.jpg | caption = Cover of ''COCORIOKO Newspaper'' (November 11, 2018), with the headline story reporting on "Former President and APC Chair [[Ernest Koroma]] meets NRM at last | type = [[Online newspaper]] | format = [[Website]] | owner = [[Leeroy Wilfred Kabs-Kanu]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1973|1|01}} (as Cocorioko) | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Somerset]], [[New Jersey]], USA. | circulation = Worldwide | image_size = 250px | publishing_country = [[United States]] and [[Sierra Leone]] | image_alt = border }}
'''COCORIOKO''' is a [[Somerset]], [[New Jersey]], [[United States]] based [[newspaper]]. It is published from different parts of the world including [[Sierra Leone]]. The websites's owner and [[editor in chief]] is [[Rev. Leeroy Wilfred Kabs-Kanu]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.musicinafrica.net/directory/cocorioko||title= Bio|year=2016|work=Music In Africa|publisher= In-house Nigeria |format=[article] |accessdate=2018-11-10}}</ref> It is published as an online website that covers political concerns, action news, commentary, editorial, sports and obituary of Sierra Leone, and the [[African diaspora]]. The Assistant Executive Officer is Foday Mansaray, Assistant CEOs are Mr. Pavi Jalloh and Bankole Gibson, and Assistant Editor is Jacob Sax-Conteh.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://cocorioko.net/about-cocorioko/|title= About Cocorioko|year=2016|work= Cocorioko Newspaper|publisher=Cocorioko|format=[article] |accessdate=2018-11-10}}</ref>
==COCORIOKO Newspaper (1973 - 1976)== [[University of Sierra Leone]] alumni students including [[His Excellency|HE]] [[Dr.]] [[Ernest Bai Koroma]] had confirmed that COCORIOKO Newspaper was first published in 1973 when the editor in chief [[Rev. Leeroy Wilfred Kabs-Kanu]] was a student at the University.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url = http://www.thepatrioticvanguard.com/kabs-kanu-is-director-of-communications|title = Kabs-Kanu is Director of Communications|date = December 11, 2007|accessdate = November 9, 2018|website =thepatrioticvanguard.com|publisher = LeoneNews|last = Vanguard|first = Patriot}}</ref> Some Sierra Leonean newspaper publishers had also said that the first COCORIOKO newspaper started with a revolutionary student's union government led by the late Boubacar Njai-Bahled, an influential student on campus. Others have affirmed that Rev. Leeroy Kabs Kanu was the Minister of [[Propaganda]] in that student's government. To them, COCORIOKO Newspaper was the voice of that student's union when they were concerned with what they described as a "battle of wits and supremacy with the college administration and political powers in the country."<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url= https://cocorioko.net/about-cocorioko/|title= About Cocorioko|year=2011|work= Cocorioko Newspaper|publisher=Cocorioko|format=[article] |accessdate=2018-11-09}}</ref>
Students from the 1973 to 1977 alumni had stated that COCORIOKO's [[Editor-In-Chief]] was Ben Ikeakor, a [[Nigerian]] student. They have said that the newspaper's editorial board members were Florence Iscandri, Millicent Macauley, Mohamed Lamin, Anthony Brewah, Princetta Godwin, Joan Mundoma, and Jaiah Kallon, who were student activists.<ref name=":7"/> The paper was said to cover the [[entertainment news]] on campus as well as the student's goals and aspirations. They claim that the student government aimed to effect change in the welfare of students on the campus.<ref name="auto"/>
Many believe that this [[student government]] "set the stage for the student revolution in 1977 headed by [[Hindolo Trye]] and that the massive students' action against the lethargic political powers forced the government to make wholesale reforms in governance which led to a snap General Elections that brought intellectuals into the national government for the first time.<ref name=":7"/> In an "About COCORIOKO" article Rev. Leeroy Wilfred Kabs Kanu stated that the paper folded up in 1976 when the main publishers graduated from college. They attest that the newspaper was very influential on the [[college campus]], attracting the attention of senior [[government officials]] and the [[media of Sierra Leone]]. However, upon graduating, they discontinued the paper.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url = https://cocorioko.net/about-cocorioko/ |title = About Cocorioko|date = April 22, 2008|accessdate = November 8, 2018|website =Cocorioko.net|publisher = Cocorioko|last = Newspaper|first = Cocorioko}}</ref>
==COCORIOKO Newspaper from the Year 2002 - 2007== Years later, Rev. Leeroy Wilfred Kabs Kanu was featured [[editor]] of "The West African Journal"" between 1995 and 1998 and "Expo Times" between 2000 and 2003.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url= https://allafrica.com/stories/200103290037.html|title=Sierra Leone: Journalist Persecuted For His Views|year=2001|work= All Africar|publisher=Mariama Massaquoi|format=[article] |accessdate=2018-11-10}}</ref> He revived his newspaper from college, COCORIOKO in 2002.<ref name=":3"/><ref name=":4">{{cite web|url = http://www.rscsl.org/Clippings/2008/2008-12/pc2008-12-15.pdf|title = Special court for sierra leone outreach and public affairs office|date = December 15, 2008|accessdate = November 8, 2018|website =rscsl.org|publisher = rscsal|last = pdf|first = rscsal}}</ref> According to [[AllAfrica.com]], Kabs Kanu resumed publishing his newspaper at "Leonenet - UMBC", which was the first Sierra Leone discussion forum set up at the advent of the internet, by Claude Meama- Kajue.<ref name="auto1"/> At the time the newspaper was called "Daily News Inquirer." The Reverend later changed the paper's name to "COCORIOKO," the name of his first newspaper the he published as a student at the University of Sierra Leone. In 2015 he stated that the “present mission of the newspaper is the rebranding of Sierra Leone.”<ref name=":3"/><ref name=":4"/>
==COCORIOKO Newspaper 2007 - 2018== Some Sierra Leoneans believe that the diligent reporting on Cocorioko newspaper greatly contributed to the [[regime change]] that took place during Sierra Leone’s 2007 [[General Elections]]. Others gather that an overwhelming number of the Sierra Leone people voted for [[Dr.]] [[Ernest Bai Koroma]] and his [[All People’s Congress]] Party (A. P. C.) during the democratic [[Presidential]] and [[Legislative]] [[Elections]] since the citizens believed Cocorioko newspaper's widely broadcast reports that the [[Sierra Leone People’s Party]] (S. L. P. P.) government of the late [[President]] HE [[Dr.]] [[Ahmed Tejan Kabbah]] was inefficient and corrupt.<ref name=":3"/><ref name=":4"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Canadian Conservation Institute''' ('''CCI''') is a special operating agency of the federal [[Department of Canadian Heritage]]. CCI provides research, information, and services regarding the [[Conservator-restorer|conservation and preservation]] of [[cultural artifact]]s.<ref name = NSERCC>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/Students-Etudiants/PD-NP/Laboratories-Laboratoires/CCI-ICC_eng.asp|title=Canadian Conservation Institute |last= |first= |date= |website= Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada |publisher= Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada |others= |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 March 2017 }}</ref><ref>A-AD-266-000/AG-001 Canadian Forces Museums –Operations and Administration 2002-04-03</ref> Materials and media it handles includes paper, textiles, metals, and glass, as well as electronic media, such as audio tape and compact discs. The CCI offices are located in the [[Ottawa]] suburb of [[Gloucester, Ontario|Gloucester]].
==Mission== The CCI is recognized as a pioneer and leader in the conservation of [[cultural heritage]] in [[Canada]].<ref name= McElhone >{{Cite web|url= http://www.ngcmagazine.ca/features/nathan-stolow-1928-2014-an-art-conservation-pioneer |title= Nathan Stolow (1928–2014): An Art Conservation Pioneer |last= McElhone |first= John |date= 12 December 2014 |website= National Gallery of Canada Magazine |publisher= [[National Gallery of Canada]] |others= |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 March 2017 }}</ref> The CCI supports the heritage community in preserving Canada's heritage collections so they can be accessed by current and future generations. The CCI is charged with the duty "to promote the proper care and perservation of Canada's moveable cultural heritage, and to advance the practice, science, and technology of conservation."<ref name= Commission >{{cite book |last= Turko |first= Karen|date= February 1996|title= Preservation Activities in Canada: A Unifying Theme in a Decentralised Country|url= https://www.clir.org/pubs/reports/pub60/pub60.pdf|location= |publisher= The Commission on Preservation and Access|page= |isbn= 1-887334-47-5|author-link= }}</ref>
==History== The CCI originated within the [[National Gallery of Canada]] in 1957, as its Conservation and Scientific Research Division under the leadership of Dr. Nathan Stolow.<ref name= McElhone /> In 1964, the division was granted greater autonomy and became the National Conservation Research Laboratory ("NCRL").<ref name= McElhone /> As a result of its success, in 1972 the NCRL was split off from the National Gallery of Canada and was renamed the Canadian Conservation Institute with Dr. Stolow as its first Director General.<ref name= McElhone /> It now operates as an agency of the federal government of Canada, currently under the auspices of the Department of Canadian Heritage.
The CCI is primarily a research organization, but provides education and services on conservation and restoration-related matters.<ref name= Commission /> The CCI now promotes the proper care and preservation of Canada's cultural heritage and to advance the practice, science, and technology of conservation. The Institute has worked closely with hundreds of Canadian museums, art galleries, archives, libraries, historic sites, academic institutions, and other heritage organizations to help them better preserve their collections.<ref name= Commission /> The primary role of CCI's clients is to acquire, conserve, research, communicate, and exhibit permanent heritage collections that are accessible to the Canadian public for purposes of study, education, and enjoyment. As a Special Operating Agency of the Department of Canadian Heritage, CCI has widened its scope of activities and now markets its services and products around the world. The CCI was included amongst other architecturally interesting and historically significant buildings in [[Doors Open Ottawa]], held June 2, 2012.<ref>http://ottawa.ca/doorsopen Doors Open Ottawa</ref>
==Programs== The following are but some of the services CCI provides:<ref name = NSERCC/><ref>{{cite news |last= Wright|first= Julia|date= 18 November 2016|title= Historic quilt stitches together Confederation story|url= http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/confederation-quilt-restored-1.3855102| work= |location= |access-date= 11 March 2017}}</ref>
* Conservation research and laboratory services. * Preventative and restorative conservation. * Transportation of artifacts. * Scientific examination and analysis of museum objects and archaeological materials. * Advice on preserving a historic house or property. * Collections assessment surveys. * Advice for conservation or restoration treatment for valuable works of art. * Conservation and restoration training.
CCI also provides project-specific teams for conservation, scientific, and testing projects. Its Paper Group works with archives and libraries in preserving and restoring their collections.<ref name= Commission /> Research conducted by the Paper Group includes paper bleaching, [[enzyme]] use, washing, and de-acidification.<ref name= Commission /><ref>{{cite journal |last= Tse |first= Season |last2= Bégin |first2= P. |date= July 2014|title= Highlights of Paper Research at the Canadian Conservation Institute |journal= Studies in Conservation |volume= 47|issue= s3|pages= 193–198|doi= 10.1179/sic.2002.47.s3.040}}</ref> The CCI also self-publishes a variety of materials related to its work.<ref name= Commission /> As well, each year it publishes the ''CCI, the Journal of the Canadian Conservation Institute''. With a staff of about 80 to 100,<ref name= Commission /> the CCI has treated more than 13,000 objects for the heritage community, has published hundreds of scientific papers, and has distributed in excess of one million publications.<ref name = NSERCC/> The Institute responds to at least 2,000 requests for assistance annually. Working together in well-equipped, fully secure, climate-controlled laboratories, [[Conservator-restorer|conservators]], [[chemists]], [[engineers]], [[biologists]], and other professionals handle projects ranging from information inquiries to complex treatments and [[research]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://canada.pch.gc.ca/eng/1454704828075 Canadian Conservation Institute]
[[Category:Canadian federal departments and agencies]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Canada]] [[Category:Scientific organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Conservation and restoration]] [[Category:Collections care]] [[Category:Art history]] [[Category:Museology]]

{{Orphan|date=October 2015}}
{{Infobox dot-com company |name = Vergelijk.nl |logo = [[File:Compare Group logo.png|300px|frameless]] |location = [[Zwolle]], [[Netherlands]] |founder =Ben Kerkhof, Jean-Paul Southout, Tjibbe de Jong |industry = [[Internet]] |products = |revenue = |assets = |equity = |url = [https://www.vergelijk.nl/ www.vergelijk.nl] |alexa =302 |advertising = |language = [[French language|French]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Flemish]] |company_type = [[Privately held company|Privately held]] |traded_as = |foundation = {{Start date|1999}} |area_served = |key_people = [[Ben Kerkhof]] (CEO), [[Joris Verwater]] (CMO), [[Maarten Janssen]] (CTO) |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = 30 |programming_language = |website_type = [[Price comparison service]] |launch_date =1999 }} '''Vergelijk.nl (Compare Group)''' is a privately held company which holds four [[price comparison services]] in three countries and was founded in [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]] in 1999.
== History ==
Vergelijk.nl was founded in 1999 by Ben Kerkhof, Jean Paul Soethout and Tjibbe de Jong and was the first [[price comparison services|price comparison website]] in the [[Netherlands]]. In 2000, Vergelijk.nl co-founder [[Ben Kerkhof]] started Vertaa.fi, a price comparison website based in [[Finland]]. Business was expanded to [[Belgium]] in 2002 with the start of Vergelijk.be and in 2006 Vergelijk.nl acquired Dutch competitor Elcheapo.nl.
Early 2015 Vergelijk.nl launched their omni-channel localised price comparison service in which not just products and offers from webshops are compared but also those of the traditional brick and mortar merchants.
'''Compare Group''' was founded shortly after the acquisition of Elcheapo.nl in 2006, in order to centralize the management of the different labels. Since the founding of the Compare Group, business was expanded further to [[France]] and French-speaking Belgium with the foundation of Comparer.fr and Comparer.be in 2009.
Although Compare Group provides some insights in monthly visitor amounts, it does not publish exact visitor numbers. It is known that in 2004 Vergelijk.nl welcomed its 20 millionth visitor since its founding in 1999 and passed the 40 million visitors mark in 2006.<ref>[http://www.marketingfacts.nl/berichten/40_miljoen_bezoekers_voor_vergelijknl 40 miljoen bezoekers voor Vergelijk.nl]</ref>
In september 2017 Vergelijk.nl and Vergelijk.be where the first CSS's in Europe allowed to participate in Google Shopping PLA's after Google was fined with a 2.4 billion euro antitrust fine. <ref>https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/business/google-eu-antitrust.html</ref> <ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-09-29/google-invites-competitors-they-fail-to-show-up</ref> <ref>https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2017/09/27/google-verbouwt-zijn-winkel-na-miljardenboete-eu-a1575035</ref> <ref>https://www.wsj.com/articles/google-rivals-ask-eu-to-toughen-measures-in-antitrust-case-1517334038</ref>
In March 2018 Vergelijk.nl and Vergelijk.be where the first CSS's in The Netherlands and Belgium to show Amazon results on its websites. <ref>https://www.telegraaf.nl/financieel/1863809/helft-producten-bij-amazon-goedkoper-dan-nederlandse-webwinkel</ref> <ref>https://www.rtlz.nl/life/producten-bij-amazon-goedkoper-dan-bij-nederlandse-webshops</ref> <ref>https://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/vergelijknl-indexeert-duitse-aanbod-amazon</ref>
=== Discontinued projects ===
*Comparestreet.co.uk, a price comparison website based in the [[United Kingdom]]. The website was founded in 2002 and discontinued in 2006. *Adultcompare.nl, a website aimed at comparing prices of erotic and adult products which was founded in 2002.<ref>[http://www.marketingfacts.nl/berichten/nieuwe_vergelijkingssite_voor_erotische_producten Nieuwe vergelijkingssite voor erotische producten]</ref> It was discontinued as a separate project in 2004 when it was integrated in Vergelijk.nl. *Superdagdeal.nl, a website founded in 2010. Superdagdeal.nl focused on offering one special deal which lasted for 24 hours. The website was sold in 2011 to GoldenExperience.<ref>[http://www.twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2011/06/vergelijk.nl-verkoopt-superdagdeal-aan-goldenexperience/ Vergelijk.nl verkoopt Superdagdeal aan GoldenExperience]</ref><ref>[http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/vergelijknl-verkoopt-site-flash-sales Vergelijk.nl verkoopt site flash sales]</ref> *Check Magazine, a print magazine by BesteProduct.nl, Vergelijk.nl, Independer.nl and Zoover, was introduced in 2008 and wrote mainly about trends and developments in online shopping.<ref>[http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/prijsvergelijkers-stappen-samen-in-papieren-magazine Prijsvergelijkers stappen samen in papieren magazine]</ref> Check Magazine was discontinued after three issues due to a lack of subscribers and advertisement revenue.<ref>[http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/vergelijkingssites-stappen-uit-papieren-magazine Vergelijkingssites stappen uit papieren magazine]</ref><ref>[http://www.adformatie.nl/nieuws/bericht/consumentenmagazine-check-stopt-voorlopig/ Consumentenmagazine Check stopt voorlopig]</ref> *July 2014: The Vergelijk.nl shopping cart: Vergelijk.nl’s take on a marketplace was discontinued because of lack of interest and usage by both the merchants and its visitors; * January 2015: Early 2015 Vergelijk.nl decided to strengthen the brand name of Vergelijk.nl in the Dutch market. Its brand ElCheapo.nl was conflicting with this so the decision was taken to discontinue this website;<ref>http://twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2015/03/vergelijk.nl-breidt-uit-met-fysieke-winkelresultaten/index.xml</ref><ref>http://twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2015/01/vergelijk.nl-verder-met-nieuwe-website/</ref> * May 2017: Discontinued Comparer.fr
=== Acquisitions === *2003: Arbalet - Belgian comparison competitor Arbalet was acquired in 2003. Its activities were incorporated and continued in Vergelijk.be. Arbalet ceased to exist as a separate entity.<ref>[http://www.nieuwsbank.nl/inp/2003/12/11/R203.htm Prijsvergelijkingssite Vergelijk.be neemt Arbalet over]</ref> *2004: Consumerdesk.nl - Consumerdesk.nl was acquired along with other assets from the bankrupt company Cedron.<ref>[http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/vergelijk-nl-neemt-ook-deel-boedel-cedron-over Vergelijk.nl neemt ook deel boedel Cedron over]</ref> *2006: Elcheapo.nl - Competing price comparison website Elcheapo.nl was acquired from [[Telegraaf Media Groep|De Telegraaf]] in 2006. No details on the acquisition have been disclosed.
== Business model ==
Vergelijk.nl’s [[business model]] consists of three main revenue drivers:
*Lead generation for web shops using a [[Pay per click|cost per click]] model. *A monthly subscription fee for the traditional brick & mortar merchants. *A [[Pay Per Sale|cost per sale]] model which provides Vergelijk.nl a percentage of the order value for every order placed on Vergelijk.nl's websites. Although Vergelijk.nl receives the orders, the actual processing of orders is done by web shops. Web shops receive the order value subtracted by Vergelijk.nl’s compensation.<ref>[http://twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2011/08/vergelijk.nl-met-shopping-beslist.nl-te-snel-af/ Vergelijk.nl met shopping Beslist.nl te snel af]. This model has been discontinued as of July 2014. [http://twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2014/08/vergelijk.nl-verder-zonder-winkelmandje/index.xml]</ref> *In 2014 Vergelijk.nl decided to terminate their marketplace /[[cost per sale model]].<ref>http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/vergelijknl-geen-webwinkel-meer</ref><ref>http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/nieuwe-strategie-nieuwe-site-vergelijknl</ref><ref>http://twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2014/08/vergelijk.nl-verder-zonder-winkelmandje/index.xml</ref>
== Revenue ==
Consolidated revenue of Compare Group:
{| class="wikitable sortable" width="20%" ! Year ! Revenue (in million €) ! Growth |- |2007 |4.7 | |- |2008 |5.0 |6.4% |- |2009 |5.4 |8% |- |2010 |6.7 |24.1% |- |2011 |8.1
|20.9% |- |2012 |9.0 |11.1% |- |2013 |8.6 |11.1% |- |2014 |8.7 |11.1% |}
No figures on profits or losses have been published by Compare Group.
== Awards ==
*2011: Comparer.fr was elected in the top 10 favorite French comparison sites.<ref>[http://www.harrisinteractive.fr/news/2011/31082011.asp Classement NetObserver® des sites préférés des internautes français ]</ref> *2012: Vergelijk.nl won the High Growth Award of its region.<ref>[http://www.port4growth.nl/events/high-growth-awards/winnaars-high-growth-awards-2012.html High Growth Awards winnaars 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829074610/http://www.port4growth.nl/events/high-growth-awards/winnaars-high-growth-awards-2012.html |date=2013-08-29 }}</ref> *2013: Vergelijk.nl was nominated for the Best Comparison Website Award at the Dutch Thuiswinkel Awards.<ref>[http://www.twinklemagazine.nl/nieuws/2013/03/genomineerden-thuiswinkel-awards-xl-2013/ Genomineerden Thuiswinkel Awards XL 2013]</ref>
== External links == Vergelijk.nl - Compare Group's comparison websites: *[http://www.vergelijk.nl/ Vergelijk.nl] *[http://www.vergelijk.be/ Vergelijk.be] *[http://www.comparer.be/ Comparer.be] *[http://www.vertaa.fi/ Vertaa.fi]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Comparison shopping websites]] [[Category:Privately held companies of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in the Netherlands]]
