{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{about|the quality rating system|classifications of astrophysical stars|stellar classification}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2012}} [[File:FiveStarsInline3.svg|thumb|A typical format for a star rating, showing three out of five stars]] '''Stars''' are often used as symbols for ratings. They are used by reviewers for ranking things such as films, TV shows, restaurants, and hotels. For example, a system of one to five stars is commonly employed to rate [[hotel]]s, with five stars being the highest quality. ==Historical usage== Repeated symbols used for ranking date to [[Mariana Starke]]'s 1820 guidebook, which used [[exclamation point]]s to indicate works of art of special value:
...I have endeavoured... to furnish Travellers with correct lists of the objects best worth notice...; at the same time marking, with one or more exclamation points (according to their merit), those works which are deemed peculiarly excellent.Mariana Starke, ''Travels on the Continent: written for the use and particular information of travellers'', London: John Murray, 1820 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rLRfAAAAcAAJ full text], p. x; later editions are entitled ''Information and Directions for Travellers on the Continent''
[[Murray's Handbooks for Travellers]] and then the [[Baedeker Guides]] (starting in 1844) borrowed this system, using stars instead of exclamation points, first for points of interest, and later for hotels.David M Bruce, "Baedeker: the Perceived Inventor of the Formal Guidebook", in Richard Butler, ed., ''Giants of Tourism'', {{ISBN|1845936523}}, p. 93-110 The [[Michelin Guide|Michelin restaurant guide]] introduced a star as a restaurant rating in 1926, and expanded to a system of one to three stars in 1931.[https://archive.is/20130505100337/http://www.viamichelin.co.uk/tpl/mag6/art200903/htm/tour-saga-michelin.htm "The Michelin Guide: 100 editions and over a century of history"] ViaMichelin, accessed 20 May 2013 ==Media== ===Books=== In 1915, [[Edward Joseph Harrington O'Brien|Edward O'Brien]] began editing [[The Best American Short Stories]]. This annual compiled O'Brien's personal selection of the previous year's best short stories. O'Brien was known to work indefatigably: he claimed to read as many as 8,000 stories a year, and his editions contained lengthy tabulations of stories and magazines, ranked on a scale of zero to three stars (representing O'Brien's notion of their "literary permanence."){{cite book|title=The Best American Short Stories of the Century|last=Kenison|first=Katrina|date=1999|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|Houghton Mifflin Company]]|isbn=0-395-84368-5|pages=viii-ix}} At the end of each book, O'Brien listed all the stories published during the preceding year. O'Brien awarded no stars to those stories which failed "to survive either the test of substance or the test of form." O'Brien listed these stories without comment or a qualifying asterisk. O'Brien awarded one star to "those stories which may fairly claim to survive either the test of substance or the test of form. Each of these stories may claim to possess either distinction of technique alone, or more frequently, I am glad to say, a persuasive sense of life in them to which a reader responds with some part of his own experience." O'Brien awarded two stars to stories "of still greater distinction" that warranted a second reading "because each of them has survived both tests, the test of substance and the test of form." O'Brien awarded three stars – the highest rating – to "a small group of stories" which had "an even finer distinction—the distinction of uniting genuine substance and artistic form in a closely woven pattern with a spiritual sincerity so earnest, and a creative belief so strong, that each of these stories may fairly claim, in my opinion, a position of some permanence in our literature as a criticism of life. O'Brien further listed these stories "in a special 'Roll of Honor.'" In this special list O'Brien further attached an additional asterisk to those stories that O'Brien personally enjoyed. "Stories indicated by this asterisk seem to me not only distinctive, but so highly distinguished as to necessitate their ultimate preservation between book covers. It is from this final short list that the stories reprinted in this volume have been selected."{{cite book|title=The Best Short Stories of 1915 And the Yearbook of the American Short Story|last=O'Brien|first=Edward J.|authorlink=Edward Joseph Harrington O'Brien|date=1916|location=Boston|publisher=Small, Maynard & Company}} [[Oliver Herford]]'s essay ''Say it with Asterisks'', quips "Never, I think, were a mob of overworked employees so pitifully huddled together in an ill-ventilated factory as are the Asterisks in this Sweatshop of Twaddle."{{cite book|last=Herford|first=Oliver|authorlink=Oliver Herford|title=Neither Here Nor There|chapter=Say it with Asterisks|date=1922}}First published in the [[Ladies' Home Journal]]. Literary editor Katrina Kenison dismisses O'Brien's grading systems as "excessive at best, fussy and arbitrary at worst." Book reviewers generally do not use a star-rating system though there are exceptions. The ''West Coast Review of Books'' rates books on a scale of one ("poor") to five ("superior") stars.{{cite journal|journal=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|title=(trade ad)|date=December 1977|page=19}} According to editor D. David Dreis, readers love the ratings but publishers don't.{{cite journal|journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|title=Book Review Aims at Masses|page=89|date=15 November 1976}} ===Films=== In the 31 July 1928 issue of the ''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]'', the newspaper's film critic Irene Thirer began grading movies on a scale of zero to three stars. Three stars meant 'excellent,' two 'good,' and one star meant 'mediocre.' And no stars at all 'means the picture's right bad,'" wrote Thirer. [[Carl Bialik]] speculates that this may have been the first time a film critic used a star-rating system to grade movies.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123265679206407369|title=Let's Rate the Ranking Systems of Film Reviews: The Stars, Grades and Thumbs Applied to Movies Suffer From Lackluster Performance, Low Production Values|date=23 January 2009|last=Bialik|first=Carl|authorlink=Carl Bialik|publisher=Wall Street Journal}} "The one-star review of ''[[The Port of Missing Girls (1928 film)|The Port of Missing Girls]]'' launched the star system, which the newspaper promised would be 'a permanent thing.' According to film scholar [[Gerald Peary]], few newspapers adopted this practice until the French film magazine ''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'' "started polling critics in the 1950s and boiling their judgment down to a star rating, with a [[Bullet (typography)|bullet]] reserved for movies that the magazine didn't like." The highest rating any film earned was five stars. The British film magazine ''[[Sight and Sound]]'' also rated films on a scale of one to four stars.{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/1996/sep/19/duncan-shepherd-replies-his-critics/?page=2|title=Duncan Shepherd Replies to His Critics|last=Shepherd|first=Duncan|date=19 September 1996|authorlink=Duncan Shepherd}} Some critics use a "half-star" option in between basic star ratings. Leonard Maltin goes one further and gives ''[[Naked Gun 33⅓: The Final Insult]]'' a 2⅓ star rating.{{sfn|Maltin||p=}} Critics do not agree what the cutoff is for a recommendation, even when they use the same scale. [[Gene Siskel]] and [[Roger Ebert]] "both consider[ed] a three-star rating to be the cutoff for a "thumbs up" on their scales of zero to four stars.{{cite news|last=Caro|first=Mark|title=A Journey Through The Stars - and Beyond: When It Comes To Rating Entertainment, You've Gotta Have A System; Star Gazing With The Movie Critics|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=2 March 1990|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-03-02/entertainment/9001180289_1_stars-siskel-ebert-rate-films}} Film critic [[Dave Kehr]] – who also uses a 0–4 star scale – believes "two stars is a borderline recommendation". On a five-star scale, regardless of the bottom rating, 3 stars is often the lowest positive rating, though judging on a purely mathematical basis, 2 1/2 stars would be the dividing line between good and bad on a 0-5 scale. [[Common Sense Media]] uses a scale of one to five, where 3 stars is "Just fine; solid" and anything lower is "Disappointing" at best.[https://www.commonsensemedia.org/about-us/our-mission/about-our-ratings Common Sense Media: About our ratings] There is no agreement on what the lowest rating should be. Some critics make "one star" or a "half-star" their lowest rating. Dave Kehr believes that "one star" indicates the film has redeeming facets, and instead uses zero stars as his lowest rating. Examples of rating scales: *0–4: [[Roger Ebert]], [[Gene Siskel]], [[David Kehr]] and [[Peter Travers]] *0.5–4: [[Steven H. Scheuer]]'s now defunct film guide grades films from a half-star ("abysmal") to four stars ("excellent").{{cite book|title=Movies on TV and Video Cassette 1989-1990|last=Scheuer|first=Steven H.|authorlink=Steven H. Scheuer|edition=13th|publisher=[[Bantam Books]]|date=1989|isbn=9780553277074|page=xiii}} Despite this Scheuer's guide intentionally gives [[Wes Craven]]'s film ''[[The Last House on the Left (1972 film)|The Last House on the Left]]'' no stars making it the lowest-rated film in the book.{{sfn|Scheuer|1989|p=440}} *0–5: ''[[The Times]]'' *1–4: Film critic [[Leonard Maltin]] rates films on a scale of one through four stars, although his guide notes that there is no actual "one star" rating. For these "bottom-of-the-barrel movies", Maltin's guide uses the citation "BOMB".{{cite book|title=Leonard Maltin's 2012 Movie Guide|last=Maltin|first=Leonard|authorlink=Leonard Maltin|publisher=[[Penguin Group]]|date=2011|isbn=9780451234476|page=xiii}} However, according to Maltin, the 1981 [[Bo Derek]] film ''[[Tarzan, the Ape Man (1981 film)|Tarzan, the Ape Man]]'' "nearly forced the editors of this book to devise a rating lower than BOMB".{{sfn|Maltin|2011|p=1378}} *1–5: [[Common Sense Media]] Critics have different ways of denoting the lowest rating when this is a "zero". Some such as [[Peter Travers]] display empty stars. [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] and [[Dave Kehr]] use a round black dot. [[Leslie Halliwell]] uses a blank space. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' uses a "0", or as their former film critic dubbed it, the "death doughnut". Roger Ebert used a thumbs-down symbol.{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19820101/REVIEWS/201010315/1023|title=''Death Wish II'' review by Roger Ebert|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=24 July 2011|date=1 January 1982}} Other critics use a [[Black Spot (Treasure Island)|black dot]]. Critics also do not agree on what the lower ratings signify, let alone the lowest rating. While Maltin's and Scheuer's guides respectively explain that lowest rated films are "BOMB(s)" and "abysmal", British film critic [[Leslie Halliwell]] instead writes that no star "indicates a totally routine production or worse; such films may be watchable but are at least equally missable."{{cite book|last=Halliwell|first=Leslie|authorlink=Leslie Halliwell|title=Halliwell's Film Guide|publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]]|date=1987|edition=5th|page=xxiv|isbn=9780684188263}} Like Halliwell and Dave Kehr, film critic [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] believes one-star films have some merit, however unlike Halliwell, Rosenbaum believes that no stars indicate a "worthless" movie.{{cite book|title=Placing Movies: The Practice of Film Criticism|last=Rosenbaum|first=Jonathan|authorlink=Jonathan Rosenbaum|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|date=1995|page=17|isbn=9780520086333}} [[Roger Ebert]] occasionally gave zero stars to films he deemed "artistically inept and morally repugnant."{{cite book|title=Bronson's Loose!: The Making of the Death Wish Films|page=53|last=Talbot|first=Paul|publisher=[[iUniverse]]|date=2006|isbn=9780595379828}} Scheuer's guide calls "one and a half star" films "poor", and "one star" films "bad".{{sfn|Scheuer|1989|p=}} Not all film critics have approved of star ratings. Film scholar [[Robin Wood (critic)|Robin Wood]] wondered if ''Sight and Sound'' readers accepted "such blackening of their characters."{{cite book|last=Wood|first=Robin|authorlink=Robin Wood (critic)|title=Hitchcock's Films Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|date=2002|page=61|isbn=9780231126953}} [[Jay Scott]] of Canada's ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' was an opponent of using symbols to summarize a review and wrote in 1992 that "When Globe editors first proposed the four-star system of rating movies about a year ago, the response from Globe critics was, to put it mildly, underwhelming."{{cite news|title=Jay Scott on Film: Introducing the death doughnut (or, this one rates a zero)|last=Scott|first=Jay|authorlink=Jay Scott|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Toronto, Ontario|date=10 January 1992|page=C.2}} More recently, [[Mark Kermode]] has expressed a dislike of star ratings (assigned to his online reviews but not his print or radio reviews) on the grounds that his verdicts are sometimes too complex to be expressed as a rating.{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/mark-kermode/mark-kermode-interview-film-critics-pr-joe-cornish-star-ratings|title=Mark Kermode interview|date=30 January 2015|accessdate=31 January 2018}} ===Comedy and theatre=== Star ratings are also given out at [[stand-up comedy]] performances and [[theatre]] productions. Star ratings are given at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]], the largest arts festival in the world. Since 2010, the [[British Comedy Guide]] has collected over 4,300 reviews of around 1,110 different acts, across 83 different publications in the form of a star rating.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/fringe/2014/features/edinburgh_fringe_best_shows_2014/|title=Best reviewed Edinburgh Fringe shows 2014|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]]|date=7 September 2015|accessdate=25 July 2015}} The use of star ratings is controversial because the public may ignore the reviews and concentrate more the star ratings alone.{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Steve|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/correspondents/2014/08/26/20814/isnt_it_time_the_stars_went_out%3F|title=Isn't it time the stars went out?|publisher=[[Chortle Awards|Chortle]]|date=26 August 2014|accessdate=25 July 2015}} ===Video games=== Star ratings are not often used to rate the quality of a video game, but are rather used within certain games for varying purposes. One notable use of the star system is to grade a player's performance in completing a [[Level (gaming)|level]] with up to three stars, used in many modern multi-level games like ''[[Angry Birds (video game)|Angry Birds]]''. This three-star rating system challenges the player to [[Replay value|repeat and fully master previously beaten levels]] in order to receive a perfect 3-star rating, which may confer other benefits or bonus content. Another use of star ratings is to denote the rarity of characters in video games where players are tasked in collecting numerous characters, such as ''[[Star Wars: Galaxy of Heroes]]'' and ''[[Marvel: Contest of Champions]]'', in which stronger and rarer characters are marked with more stars to make them appear more valuable. ==Restaurant ratings== {{main|Restaurant rating}} Restaurant guides and reviewers often use stars in [[restaurant rating|restaurant ratings]]. The Michelin system reserves stars for exceptional restaurants, and gives up to three; the vast majority of recommended restaurants have no star at all. Other guides now use up to four or five stars, with one-star being the lowest rating. The stars are sometimes replaced by symbols such as a fork or spoon. Some guides use separate scales for food, service, ambiance, and even noise level. The Michelin system remains the best known star system. A single star denotes "a very good restaurant in its category", two stars "excellent cooking, worth a detour", and three stars, "exceptional cuisine, worth a special journey". {{Cite book | title = Le Guide Rouge: Paris 2003 | publisher =Michelin Editions de Voyages |date= 2003 | location = Paris, France | page = 16 | isbn = 2-06-100694-9 }} Michelin stars are awarded only for the quality of food and wine; the luxury level of the restaurant is rated separately, using a scale of one ("quite comfortable") to five ("luxury in the traditional style") crossed fork and spoon symbols. ==Hotel ratings== {{main|Hotel rating}} [[File:The Leading Hotels of the World.jpg|thumb|"Five-star superior" rating at the [[Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten Kempinski]] in [[Munich]], Germany]] Hotel luxury is often denoted by stars. Other classifiers, such as the [[AAA Five Diamond Award]], use [[Lozenge|diamonds]] instead of stars to express hotel ratings levels. Hotels are assessed in traditional systems and rest heavily on the facilities provided. Some consider this disadvantageous to smaller hotels whose quality of accommodation could fall into one class but the lack of an item such as an [[elevator]] would prevent it from reaching a higher categorization.{{Cite journal|last1=Vine |first1=P.A.L. |date=March 1981 |title=Hotel classification; art or science? |journal=International Journal of Tourism Management |publisher=Elsevier Science Ltd. |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=18–29 |doi=10.1016/0143-2516(81)90014-1 }} (Requires purchase of a document for $31.50) In recent years hotel rating systems have also been criticized by some{{who|date=September 2018}} who argue that the rating criteria for such systems are overly complex and difficult for laymen to understand. It has been suggested that the lack of a unified global system for rating hotels may also undermine the usability of such schemes. == Financial product ratings == In the UK, providers and comparison websites often use Stars to indicate how feature-rich financial products are.{{Cite web|title = Defaqto Ratings at Gocompare.com|url = http://www.gocompare.com/defaqto/|website = www.gocompare.com|accessdate = 7 September 2015}} [[Defaqto]] is an organisation that independently assess every financial product in the UK. Each of these products is awarded a rating from 1 to 5 Stars, allowing consumers to see where it sits in the market. The higher the Star Rating, the more comprehensive a product. [[Defaqto|Defaqto Star Ratings]] are calculated using a scoring system of between 40 and 100 features and benefits for each product or insurance policy, with each scored from 1 to 5. The scores for each product are totalled and all products ranked. Our industry experts determine the scores necessary to achieve 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 Star Ratings.{{Cite web|title = What are Star Ratings? {{!}} Defaqto|url = https://www.defaqto.com/star-ratings/star-ratings/what-are-star-ratings/|website = www.defaqto.com|accessdate = 7 September 2015}} ==Military ranks== The most senior [[military rank]]s in all services are classified by a star system in many countries, ranging from [[one-star rank]] which typically corresponds to [[brigadier]], [[brigadier general]], [[commodore (rank)|Commodore]] or [[air commodore]], to the most senior [[five-star rank]]s which include [[Admiral of the Fleet]], [[Grand Admiral]], [[Field Marshal]], [[General of the Army]] and [[Marshal of the Air Force]] which typically only exist during large-scale conflicts. The North Korean rank of [[Taewonsu]] has been compared to a seven-star rank. In the [[Irish Army|army]] of the [[Republic of Ireland]], the most junior ranks are classified by stars. A three-star [[private (rank)|private]]/[[gunner (rank)|gunner]]/[[trooper (rank)|trooper]] is one who is considered a fully trained soldier. Two-star privates/gunners/troopers are those who have completed basic training but have not yet completed other specialised training necessary for their roles. One-star privates do not exist: the lowest rank is recruit. Senior officers are classified as Brigadiers, Majors General and Lts General. {{Star officer ranks |state=collapsed}} ==Other== ===Manufactured home park rating=== There is no official star rating system for manufactured home parks because there is no rating organization. For such an organization to exist would require agreement between the owners of approximately 50,000 parks in the United States.{{cite web | last = Rolfe | first = Frank | title = Let’s Give up on the Star System | work = MobileHomeParkStore.com | publisher = NicheInvestments.com | date = 17 September 2012 | url = http://www.mobilehomeparkstore.com/articles/lets-give-up-on-the-star-system/ | accessdate = 29 April 2014}} A residual belief in such a system probably originated in a directory of mobile home parks printed in the 1970s, in which each park was assessed with a five star rating system.{{cite web | last = Alcorn | first = Ray | title = Mobile Home Park "Star" Ratings: Fact or Illusion? | publisher = CRE Online | url = http://www.creonline.com/mobile-home-park-star-ratings.html | accessdate = 30 April 2014}} === American college football === Recruits entering American [[college football]] are commonly ranked on a five-star scale, with five representing what scouts think will be the best college players.{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/college-football-recruiting/2018/1/26/16936186/recruiting-stars-rankings-high-school-football|title=This is how rare it is to be a blue-chip college football recruit|work=SBNation.com|first=Alex|last= Kirshner|date=Jan 26, 2018|accessdate=November 30, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/college-football/news/2017-pro-bowl-rosters-do-recruiting-star-ratings-actually-predict-nfl-success/|title=2017 Pro Bowl rosters: Do recruiting star ratings actually predict NFL success?|work=CBS Sports|first= Ben|last= Kercheval|date=Dec 21, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2018}} ===Transport safety=== International organisations use a star rating to rank the safety of transportation. [[EuroRAP]] have developed a Road Protection Score which is a scale for Star Rating roads for how well they protect the user from death or disabling injury when a crash occurs. The assessment evaluates the safety that is 'built into' the road through its design, in combination with the way traffic is managed on it.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurorap.org/rps|title=What is Star Rating?|work=EuroRAP|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316211923/http://www.eurorap.org/rps| archivedate=16 March 2008|dead-url=yes }} The RPS protocol has also been adapted and used by AusRAP, usRAP and iRAP. [[EuroNCAP]] awards 'star ratings' based on the performance of vehicles in crash tests, including front, side and pole impacts, and impacts with pedestrians. The United States [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) also uses a star ranking to rank the safety of vehicles in crash tests, including front, side, pole impacts, and rollovers, with 5 stars being the most secure.{{cite web|url=https://www.nhtsa.gov/ratings|title=Ratings|work=NHTSA|accessdate=November 30, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130185222/https://www.nhtsa.gov/ratings|archive-date=November 30, 2018|dead-url=no}} ===Voting and preferences=== Some [[Web content voting]] systems use five-star grades. This allows users to distinguish content more precisely than with binary "[[like button]]s". Many [[recommender system]]s, such as [[MovieLens]] or [[Amazon.com]], ask people to express preferences using star ratings, then predict what other items those people are likely to enjoy. Predictions are often expressed in terms of the number of predicted stars. ==Unicode== The [[Unicode]] Standard encodes several characters used for star ratings:{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2016/16254-n4747-halfstars.pdf|title=L2/16-254: Final proposal to encode four half star symbols|date=12 September 2016|first1=Ken|last1=Shirriff|first2=Andrew|last2=West|authorlink2=Andrew West (linguist)}}{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org|title=Unicode character database|work=The Unicode Standard|accessdate=9 July 2016}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Character ! Code point ! Name |- | {{huge|★}} || U+2605 || BLACK STAR |- | {{huge|☆}} || U+2606 || WHITE STAR |- | {{huge|⯪}} || U+2BEA || STAR WITH LEFT HALF BLACK |- | {{huge|⯫}} || U+2BEB || STAR WITH RIGHT HALF BLACK |- | {{huge|⯨}} || U+2BE8 || LEFT HALF BLACK STAR |- | {{huge|⯩}} || U+2BE9 || RIGHT HALF BLACK STAR |} The STAR WITH LEFT HALF BLACK and LEFT HALF BLACK STAR are intended for use in [[left-to-right]] contexts where the half star is positioned to the right of one or more whole stars, whereas the STAR WITH RIGHT HALF BLACK and RIGHT HALF BLACK STAR are intended for use in [[right-to-left]] contexts (such as [[Arabic script|Arabic]] or [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]]) where the half star is positioned to the left of one or more whole stars. ==See also== *[[One star (disambiguation)]] *[[Two star (disambiguation)]] *[[Three star (disambiguation)]] *[[Four star (disambiguation)]] *[[Five star (disambiguation)]] *[[Six star (disambiguation)]] *[[Seven star (disambiguation)]] *[[Ten star (disambiguation)]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Star (Classification)}} [[Category:Star ranking systems| ]] [[Category:Star symbols]] [[Category:Reputation management]] [[Category:Military ranks]] [[Category:Rating systems]]

The '''Symmachian forgeries''' are a sheaf of [[Forgery|forged documents]] produced in the papal [[curia]] of [[Pope Symmachus]] (498–514) in the beginning of the sixth century, in the same cycle that produced the ''[[Liber Pontificalis]]''.{{refn|[[Ignaz von Döllinger|Johann Joseph Ignaz von Döllinger]], ''Die Papst-Fabeln des Mittelalters'' 1890:57ff; [[Louis Duchesne]] and Friedrich Maassen, ''Geschichte der Quellen und Literatur des Canonischen Rechts'', vol. I 1870:798ff; W. T. Townsend, "The so-called Symmachian Forgeries", ''The Journal of Religion'' '''13'''.2 (April 1933:165-174): Townsend made a plea that these "reconstructions of history" were not ''intended'' as forgeries and that critics "have not given their first readers due credit for a saving sense of humor" (p. 165, 167), and identifies subjects of criticism as the supporters of [[Theoderic the Great|Theodoric]], namely [[Cassiodorus]], [[Liberius (praetorian prefect)|archpresbyter Liberius]] and Faustus.<ref>Townsend does not precisely identify who Faustus was. One possibility is [[Anicius Acilius Aginantius Faustus]] ("Faustus ''albus''"), who is known to have served under [[Odoacer]], Theodoric's immediate predecessor. Theodoric wrote a letter to one Faustus, ''[[Praepositus sacri cubiculi|praepositus]]''.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/pdfplus/10.1086/481294 |title=The So-called Symmachian Forgeries |first=W. T. |last=Townsend |website=[[University of Chicago]] |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>}} In the context of the conflict between partisans of Symmachus and [[Antipope Laurentius]] the purpose of these ''[[Libellus|libelli]]'' was to further papal pretensions of the independence of the [[Bishops of Rome]] from criticisms and judgment of any ecclesiastical tribunal, putting them above law clerical and secular by supplying spurious documents supposedly of an earlier age. "During the dispute between Pope St. Symmachus and the [[Antipope Laurentius|anti-pope Laurentius]]," the ''[[Catholic Encyclopedia]]'' reports, "the adherents of Symmachus drew up four apocryphal writings called the 'Symmachian Forgeries'. ... The object of these forgeries was to produce alleged instances from earlier times to support the whole procedure of the adherents of Symmachus, and, in particular, the position that the Roman bishop could not be judged by any court composed of other bishops."<ref>{{Catholic Encyclopedia|prescript=|title=Pope St. Symmachus|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14377a.htm}}</ref>
Their editor [[Louis Duchesne]] divided them in two groups, a group produced in the heat of the conflict involving Symmachus and a later group. Among writings to support Symmachus, ''Gesta de Xysti purgatione'' narrated a decision by [[Pope Sixtus III|Sixtus III]], who cleared his name from defamation and permanently excommunicated the offender; ''Gesta de Polychronii episcopi Hierosolynitani accusatione'' concerned a purely apocryphal [[Simony|simonical]] [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|Bishop of Jerusalem]] "Polychronius", who claimed Jerusalem as the first see and his supremacy over other bishops; ''Gesta Liberii papae'' concerned mass baptisms carried out by [[Pope Liberius]] during his exile from the seat of Peter; ''[[Pseudo-Council of Sinuessa|Sinuessanae synodi]] gesta de Marcellino'' recounted the accusation brought against [[Pope Marcellinus]], that in the company of the Emperor [[Diocletian]] he had offered incense to the pagan gods, making the point that when Marcellinus eventually confessed to the misdeed it was declared that the pope had [[papal renunciation|condemned himself]], since no one had ever judged the pontiff, because the first see will not be judged by anyone.<ref>Townsend 1933:168–171.</ref>
The most important in this group of forgeries was ''Silvestri constitutum'', a report of a fictitious synod convoked by [[Pope Sylvester I|Pope Sylvester]], giving twenty promulgated canons, among which was a prohibition of bringing a solitary accusation upon an ecclesiastic of a degree higher than the accuser's: a bishop might only be accused by seventy-two, and a pope could not be accused by anyone. ''Silvestri constitutum'' was also an early instance of the fable that Sylvester had cured [[Constantine the Great]] of [[leprosy]] with the waters of [[baptism]], incurring the Emperor's abject gratitude, which was elaborated and credited to the point that, in greeting [[Pope Stephen II]] in 753, [[Pepin II]] dismounted to lead the Pope's horse to his palace on foot, as Constantine would have done.<ref>This anecdote itself is reported in the ''Vita Stefani'' of the ''[[Liber Pontificalis]]'', a source concerned to maintain papal ''auctoritas''.</ref>
The second, somewhat later group centers on the figure of Sylvester, who accepts the decree of the [[First Council of Nicaea]] on the [[Easter controversy|date of Easter]]. One of these forgeries reports a fictitious synod convoking 275 bishops in the [[Baths of Trajan]]; several canons exalt the position of the cleric.<ref>Townsend 1933:171.</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[Donation of Constantine]]

{{for|the discount cookbook purchasing program|Bookspan}} {{italic title}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''''The Good Cook''''' was a series of instructional cookbooks published by [[Time-Life Books]] 1978-1980 and sold on a month-to-month basis until the early 1990s and edited by cookbook author [[Richard Olney (food writer)|Richard Olney]]. Each [[Volume (bibliography)|volume]] was dedicated to a specific subject (such as meat or poultry) and was heavily illustrated with photos of cooking techniques. The 28 volumes were as follows: Beef and Veal
Beverages
Biscuits/Cookies and Crackers (US title)
Breads
Cakes and Pastries/Cakes (US)
Confectionery/Candy (US)
Desserts/Classic Desserts (US)
Eggs and Cheese
Fish and Shellfish (two separate volumes, US)
Fruits
Game (UK only)
Grains, Pasta and Pulses/Dried Beans and Grains (US)
Hot Hors d'Oeuvres/Hors d'Oeuvres
Lamb
Offal/Variety Meats (US)
Outdoor Cooking
Pasta (US only)
Patisserie/Pies and Pastries (US)
Pork
Poultry
Preserving
Salads and cold Hors-d'Oeuvre/Salads (US)
Sauces
Snacks and Canapes/Snacks and Sandwiches (US)
Soups
Terrines, Pates and Galantines
Vegetables
Wine ==See also== *''[[Foods of the World]]'' - a similar Time-Life cookbook series *[[Richard Olney (food writer)|Richard Olney]] - Chief Series Consultant of "The Good Cook" book set {{DEFAULTSORT:Good Cook}} [[Category:Cookbooks]] {{Food-book-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = The Literature of Australian Birds | title_orig = | translator = | image = | caption = | author = [[Hubert Whittell|Hubert Massey Whittell]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Australia | language = English | series = | subject = Australian ornithology | genre = History and bibliography | publisher = Paterson Brokensha Pty Ltd | pub_date = 1954 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = xii + 116 + 788 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Literature of Australian Birds''''' is a book published in 1954 by Paterson Brokensha in [[Perth, Western Australia]]. Its full title is '''''The Literature of Australian Birds: A History and a Bibliography of Australian Ornithology'''''. It was authored by [[Hubert Whittell|Hubert Massey Whittell]]. It is in large [[octavo]] format (252 x 184 mm) and contains some 900 pages, two separately paginated parts bound in one volume in brown buckram. It contains a coloured frontispiece (Plate 1) of a drawing of the [[superb lyrebird]] by Lieutenant-General [[Thomas Davies (British Army officer)|Thomas Davies]] from 1799, with another 31 [[black-and-white]] plates bound between Parts 1 and 2. Part 1, titled “A History of Australian Ornithology 1618 to 1850”, is 116 pages in length. It covers the period from the exploratory Dutch voyages of the early 17th century to the voyages of [[HMS Fly (1831)|HMS ''Fly'']] and [[HMS Rattlesnake (1822)|HMS ''Rattlesnake'']] during 1842-1850. Much the larger part of the book, however, lies in the 788 pages of Part 2, titled “A Bibliography of Australian Ornithology 1618 to 1950, with Biographies of Authors, Collectors and Others”, where Whittell has attempted to be exhaustively comprehensive in compiling mentions of Australian birds, not only from the scientific literature but also from newspapers, magazines and other published sources, and including potted biographies of their authors. The two parts of the book are dedicated separately, Part 1: "To [[Dominic Serventy|D.L.S.]] in Appreciation of our long Association in Australian Ornithology", and Part 2: "In Memoriam. [[Gregory Mathews|GREGORY MACALISTER MATHEWS C.B.E.]]. A Pioneer Bibliographer of the Literature of Australian Birds. OBIT 1947."Whittell (1954). A facsimile edition was published by Oak Knoll Press in 1993 ({{ISBN|1888262680}}). In 1995 the [[Bird Observers Club of Australia]] (BOCA) published BOCA Report Number 6 – “Whittell (1618-1950) Supplemented. Additions and Emendations to H.M. Whittell’s The Literature of Australian Birds”, compiled by Tess Kloot. In the preface to this latter work Kloot comments, with regard to Whittell:
”In his monumental work, ''The Literature of Australian Birds'', (Paterson Brokensha Pty Ltd, 1954), the late Major H. M. Whittell paid tribute to those who went before him : In 1925 [[Gregory Mathews|Gregory M. Mathews]] issued, as a supplement to his ''Birds of Australia'', a bibliography of books and articles studied in the preparation of his work, plus brief biographical notes on the authors; and in 1935 Anthony Musgrave published his ''Bibliography of Australian Entomology 1775-1930''. In turn, I can do no better than pay tribute to Major Whittell. With his book constantly before me as I worked, I never ceased to wonder at his exhaustive research and meticulous attention to detail. It is indeed a remarkable achievement. I offer this modest contribution (and later, ''A Bio-bibliography of Australian Ornithology: 1951-1975'') in the hope that others who come after me will build upon my work.”Kloot (1995).
==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Sources=== * {{cite book |title= Whittell (1618-1950) Supplemented. Additions and Emendations to H.M. Whittell’s The Literature of Australian Birds |author= Kloot, Tess|year= 1995|publisher= Bird Observers Club of Australia|location= Melbourne|isbn= |pages= |url= }} * {{cite book |title= The Literature of Australian Birds |author= Whittell, Hubert Massey|year= 1954|publisher= Paterson Brokensha|location= Perth|isbn= |pages= |url= }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Literature of Australian Birds}} [[Category:1954 books]] [[Category:Published bibliographies]] [[Category:Ornithological literature]] [[Category:Books about Australian natural history]] [[Category:Books about Australian history]]

revision.text:
'''The Power of Poison''' is an immersive [[Science museum|science exhibit]] designed by the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in [[New York City]]. The exhibit explores poison’s roles in nature, health, history, literature, and myth.<ref>{{cite web|title="The Power of Poison" is Fall's Special Exhibition|url=http://www.amnh.org/explore/news-blogs/news-posts/fall-s-special-exhibition-is-the-power-of-poison|publisher=AMNH|accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> The show attempts to unify various studies prevalent with the museum's research facilities in order to illustrate the fluidity between the fields. It was designed by the [[AMNH Exhibitions Lab]]. ==Locations== * New York City: American Museum of Natural History, 16 November 2013 - 10 August 2014<ref name="American Museum of Natural History">{{cite web|title=Past Exhibitions: The Power of Poison|url=http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/past-exhibitions/the-power-of-poison|website=www.amnh.org|accessdate=13 August 2014}}</ref> * Atlanta, Georgia: [[Fernbank Museum of Natural History]], 7 February 2015 - 3 May 2015<ref>{{cite web|title=The Power of Poison|url=https://www.fernbankmuseum.org/explore-exhibits/special-exhibitions/the-power-of-poison/|website=www.fernbankmuseum.org|publisher=Fernbank Museum of Natural History|accessdate=13 August 2014}}</ref> ==Layout== The exhibit has four major sections, each highlighting poison as viewed by a different branch of science.
'''Biology''' *Poison Alive The exhibit opens with three small live animals, showing poison as a universal characteristic of the biosphere. *The Chocó Rainforest Ascending a small platform, visitors enter a lengthy walkthrough diorama of Colombia’s dense Chocó lowland forest. As visitors walk through the rainforest, they encounter specimens that utilize poison in their daily lives. The purpose of the section is to examine poison in a context of multiple evolutionary strategies—including linked variations in the strength of a predator’s poison and the resistance of its prey.
'''Anthropology''' *Myths and Legends Exiting the forest, visitors find themselves in a fairytale-like series of dioramas depicting poison in mythology. These include [[Grimm's Fairy Tales|Grimm's Folktales]], [[Alice in Wonderland]] and [[Macbeth]]. Curated by the museum's social sciences departments, a selection of prominent historical artifacts are incorporated into the dioramas, revealing ways humans have imagined the presence of poisons. These, in the words of the designers, are meant to show "the potent power of poison as a longstanding motif in fairy tales, legends, and children’s stories." *Poison in History A winding gallery takes visitors past life-sized models of some of history's most famous poisonings, such as Mozart's supposed death, Cleopatra’s snakebite and Napoleon’s poisoning by arsenic.
'''Forensics''' *Dissecting Poison Theater The "Dissecting Poison Theater" is a live show that describes how forensic anthropologists can detect poison. Visitors explore a real-world poisoning case that highlights advances in toxicology and forensics since the 19th century. This section is tied in with an iPad game, where visitors can solve their own forensic mystery.
'''Health Sciences''' *Poison by Accident This section uses three large forced perspective dioramas to tell stories about poison's dangerous and mercurial nature. *Poison as Cure The exhibit's finale takes guests through a diorama illustrating natural poisons that can ameliorate cancer, quinsy, laryngitis, croup, and other global health problems.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Power of Poison}} [[Category:American Museum of Natural History]] [[Category:Exhibitions in the United States]] [[Category:Poisons]] [[Category:Science exhibitions]]

[[File:Voltri-xv.JPG| thumb| ''Voltri XV'']] '''''Voltri XV''''' is an abstract sculpture by [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]].
It is part of the Voltri series created in May through June 1962 in Italy.<ref>http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=4489916</ref> He worked at an abandoned steel factory, where he welded scrap steel. With assistants, he produced Twenty Six sculptures in thirty days.<ref>''A Garden for Art'', Valerie J. Fletcher, LOC # 97-61991, p.82</ref>
It showed at [[Festival dei Due Mondi|Spoleto, Italy]],<ref>http://www.davidsmithestate.org/Candida%20Fields%20Photos/9862.008_lg_cr.html</ref> the [[White House]],<ref>http://www.sculpture.org/documents/scmag98/1lady/sm-1lady.shtml</ref> and the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]],<ref>http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/robinson/robinson2-7-06_detail.asp?picnum=4</ref> and is at the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://hirshhorn.si.edu/visit/collection_object.asp?key=32&subkey=12659 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-05-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607013515/http://www.hirshhorn.si.edu/visit/collection_object.asp?key=32&subkey=12659 |archive-date=2010-06-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]]
==References== [[File:Voltri XV.jpg|thumb| left]] {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bluffton.edu/~sullivanm/hirshhorn/hirshhorn7.html "The Hirshhorn Sculpture Gardens"], ''Bluffton'' *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/wallyg/3624588819/ Voltri XV] *[http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM9DTV_Voltri_XV_Washington_DC Waymarking]

{{Infobox book |name = Where Once We Walked |image = Where Once We Walked.jpg|caption = |author = [[Gary Mokotoff]], [[Sallyann Amdur Sack]] |country = United States |language = English |cover_artist = |series = |genre = [[genealogy]] |publisher = [[Avotaynu]] Inc. |release_date = 2002 |media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) |pages = 736 |isbn = 1-886223-15-7 |dewey = 940/.04924/00254 21 |congress = DS135.E83 M65 2002 |oclc = 50768697 |preceded_by = |followed_by = }} '''''Where Once We Walked''''' (full title: ''Where Once We Walked: A Guide to the Jewish Communities Destroyed in The Holocaust''), compiled by noted [[genealogist]] [[Gary Mokotoff]] and [[Sallyann Amdur Sack]], is a [[gazetteer]] of 37,000 town names in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]] focusing on those with [[Jewish people|Jewish]] populations in the 19th and first half of the 20th centuries and most of whose Jewish communities were almost or completely destroyed during [[The Holocaust]].
== Overview == The book includes a [[cross-reference]]d listing of some 23,000 towns (plus [[Cities' alternative names|alternate names]]), with the contemporary spelling being primary, associated country (according to contemporary borders), orientation and distance in kilometers from the country's [[capital city]], and [[map coordinates]]. The main list is followed by an additional listing organized according to a [[phonetic]] index based on the [[Daitch–Mokotoff Soundex]] system.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mokotoff|first1=Gary|authorlink1=Gary Mokotoff|last2=Amdur Sack|first2=Sallyann|title=Where Once We Walked: A Guide to the Jewish Communities Destroyed in the Holocaust|url= |edition=first|year=1991|publisher=Avotaynu|location=Teaneck, N.J.|isbn=0-9626373-1-9|pages= }}</ref>
== Revised edition == A second, revised edition (2002), expanded with additional entries and alternate names, provides updated spellings reflecting current geopolitical naming conventions.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mokotoff|first1=Gary|authorlink1=Gary Mokotoff|last2=Amdur Sack|first2=Sallyann|title=Where Once We Walked: A Guide to the Jewish Communities Destroyed in the Holocaust|url= |edition=second, revised|year=2002|publisher=Avotaynu|location=Bergenfield, N.J.|isbn=1-886223-15-7|pages= }}</ref> ''Judaica Librarianship'' called ''Where Once We Walked'', "the de facto print gazetteer of the [[Shtetl|shtetlekh]] of the [[Pale of Settlement]]."<ref name="DwoskinUpdate">{{cite journal |last1=Dwoskin |first1=Beth |title=Genealogy in the Jewish Library: An Update |journal=JJudaica Librarianship |date=2009 |volume=15 |page=13 |url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/876181053/F71FB64C2C564715PQ/2?accountid=10226 |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[JewishGen]] *[[List of villages and towns depopulated of Jews during the Holocaust]] *[[List of shtetls]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.jewishgen.org/Communities/LocTown.asp JewishGen Gazetteer and JewishGen Communities Database] search engines of the [http://www.jewishgen.org/ JewishGen] website. *[http://findingaids.cjh.org/?pID=1387354 Sallyann Sack Papers] P-917; American Jewish Historical Society, Boston, MA and New York, NY.
[[Category:1991 books]] [[Category:History books about the Holocaust]] [[Category:Books about cultural geography]] [[Category:Gazetteers]] [[Category:Books about Jews and Judaism]] [[Category:Jewish genealogy]]
